paragraph.text: The amount of assistance to be paid under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be computed with regard to the income of the stepparent if the total income of the stepparent equals or exceeds 50% of the official poverty level, adjusted for family size, established under the federal Community Services Block Grant Act.

subsection.text: A dependent child over the age of 17 years is eligible for inclusion in the FIP grant if:

paragraph.text: the child is a full–time student in secondary school or the equivalent; and
the education program is expected to be completed in the calendar year that the child attains the age of 19 years.

section.on-what: in effect if federal funds declined
section.caption: ** CONTINGENCY – NOT IN EFFECT – CHAPTER 229 OF 2002 **

paragraph.text: For applicants to the FIP, the amount of assistance shall be computed by counting no more than 4 weeks of earned income in any month and disregarding 20% of that earned income.

For eligible recipients who obtain unsubsidized employment, the amount of assistance shall be computed by counting no more than 4 weeks of earned income in any month and disregarding 35% of that earned income.

subsection.text: A recipient who has established eligibility may not lose eligibility solely because one or more wage earners in the family unit works more than 100 hours per month.
Two–parent families shall be exempt from any requirement that the principal wage earner must have worked for a specified time before applying to the FIP.

paragraph.text: A child who is living with the child’s parent and a stepparent in a household in which the household income exceeds the State eligibility standard for assistance may receive assistance if:

subparagraph.text: the requirements of § 5–308 of this subtitle are met; and
the parent and the child would be eligible for assistance, based on the income of the parent and that parent’s children.

paragraph.text: The amount of assistance to be paid under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be computed with regard to the income of the stepparent if the total income of the stepparent equals or exceeds 50% of the official poverty level, adjusted for family size, established under the federal Community Services Block Grant Act.

subsection.text: A dependent child over the age of 17 years is eligible for inclusion in the FIP grant if:

paragraph.text: the child is a full–time student in secondary school or the equivalent; and
the education program is expected to be completed in the calendar year that the child attains the age of 19 years.

subsection.text: All assistance granted under this subtitle is subject to periodic recertification.
At any time, the Department may cancel, suspend, or revoke assistance if:

paragraph.text: the recipient’s circumstances have altered sufficiently to warrant cancellation, suspension, or revocation; or
the recipient has failed to comply with FIP requirements.

subsection.text: This section is not intended to create an incentive for individuals to seek temporary cash assistance benefits instead of employment.
A local department shall provide temporary cash assistance to an applicant or recipient only if:

paragraph.text: the applicant or recipient meets the requirements for participation in the FIP set forth in § 5–308 of this subtitle;

the applicant or recipient assigns to the State all right, title, and interest in support, for the period that the family receives temporary cash assistance, from any other person that the applicant or recipient has on behalf of any intended or potential recipient for whom the applicant or recipient is applying for or receiving assistance; and
in the case of an applicant or recipient who is a minor parent, the applicant or recipient lives:

subparagraph.text: with a parent, legal guardian, custodian, or other adult relative who will be the payee of the minor parent;
in an adult–supervised group living arrangement that provides a protective payee and:

sub-subparagraph.text: there is no available parent, legal guardian, custodian, or other adult relative with whom the minor parent can live;
the minor parent or child would be subject to physical or emotional harm, sexual abuse, or neglect in the home of any available adult relative; or
a social service worker finds that living with any available adult relative would not be in the best interest of the minor parent or child; or

subparagraph.text: independently, if a social service worker confirms that the physical safety or emotional health of the minor parent or child would otherwise be in jeopardy.

subsection.text: A recipient who meets the requirements of the FIP is entitled to temporary cash assistance benefits.

In determining the eligibility for and the amount of temporary cash assistance to be provided to an applicant or recipient who is a legal immigrant, the income and resources of the applicant or recipient shall include, for the period of time established by federal law, the income and resources of any sponsor who executed an affidavit of support in accordance with 8 U.S.C. § 1183a on behalf of the legal immigrant.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations that establish a schedule of reductions and terminations of temporary cash assistance for noncompliance with FIP requirements.

subparagraph.text: If a recipient is found to be in noncompliance with FIP requirements, a caseworker shall investigate the reasons for noncompliance.
The investigation, to the extent resources allow, shall include personal contact with the family of the recipient.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may not reduce or terminate temporary cash assistance to a family until 30 days after the day on which the first written notice of noncompliance was sent to the recipient.
For noncompliance with a FIP requirement other than a work activity, temporary cash assistance shall resume on compliance with the FIP requirement.
For noncompliance with a work activity, temporary cash assistance shall resume in the following manner:

subparagraph.text: for the first instance of noncompliance, temporary cash assistance shall resume immediately on compliance;
for the second instance of noncompliance, temporary cash assistance shall resume after 10 days of compliance with the work activity; and
for each subsequent instance of noncompliance, temporary cash assistance shall resume after 30 days of compliance with a work activity.

paragraph.text: If temporary cash assistance is reduced or terminated under this subsection, a recipient shall retain eligibility for medical assistance and food stamps, as long as the recipient meets the medical assistance and food stamp program requirements.
After termination of temporary cash assistance under this section, a recipient may receive transitional assistance.

If a caseworker determines that transitional assistance is appropriate, the FIP benefit that would have been paid to the recipient shall be paid instead to a third party payee on behalf of the recipient for a period of up to 3 months.
The caseworker of a recipient, in conjunction with the recipient and subject to the approval of the Secretary, shall select a third party payee described in paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The third party payee shall provide transitional assistance to the recipient in one or more of the following forms:

subparagraph.text: counseling;
housing;
child care;
household supplies and equipment;
direct assistance other than a cash payment; and
any other noncash assistance that may be necessary to assist the recipient to make the transition from welfare.

paragraph.text: A local department may pay an administrative fee to a third party payee to cover the administrative costs of the third party payee for providing the services described in paragraph (4) of this subsection.
The funds provided through transitional assistance may not be used to further sectarian religious instruction.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations specifying the selection criteria for third party payees under this subsection.
A recipient who has received transitional assistance may reapply for the FIP benefit and the benefit shall be furnished with reasonable promptness to all eligible individuals.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section and in regulations that the Secretary adopts, a local department may not pay temporary cash assistance to:

paragraph.text: a family that includes an adult who has received more than 60 cumulative months of temporary cash assistance funded wholly or partly by federal funds; or
a family that includes an adult who:

subparagraph.text: has received more than 24 cumulative months of temporary cash assistance funded wholly or partly by federal funds; and
is not participating in a work activity.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations that establish:

paragraph.text: standards and procedures under which a local department may exempt a family from the limitation under subsection (a)(1) of this section because of hardship; and
a separate State program that:

subparagraph.text: is funded entirely from State general funds that may be counted toward any federal maintenance of effort requirement;
pays temporary cash assistance to a family that is exempted under item (1) of this subsection but cannot receive federal funds because of federal limitations; and
is subject to all FIP requirements under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section are subject to federal law and regulation.
In this section, “addictions specialist” means an addictions specialist who is located on-site at a local department.

paragraph.text: An addictions specialist shall assess the need of any adult or minor parent applicant or recipient for substance abuse treatment:

subparagraph.text: at the initial application for temporary cash assistance; or
when considered appropriate by the FIP case manager of the local department.

paragraph.text: The addictions specialist shall screen the applicant or recipient to expose potential barriers that the applicant or recipient may have in obtaining employment such as a substance abuse problem.
The addictions specialist shall inform each adult or minor parent applicant or recipient of the requirements of FIP regarding substance abuse treatment.
If the applicant or recipient does not complete the screening required under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the addictions specialist shall notify the FIP case manager.
If the screening performed by the addictions specialist reveals that an applicant or recipient has a substance abuse problem, the addictions specialist shall:

subparagraph.text: conduct, or refer for, an assessment of the applicant’s or recipient’s substance abuse problem and, if appropriate, determine placement for treatment and related support services;
refer the applicant or recipient for appropriate substance abuse treatment and related support services;
obtain the signature of the applicant or recipient on a form consenting to the release of confidential substance abuse treatment information;
forward the consent form to the appropriate substance abuse treatment provider; and
obtain any necessary treatment information from the substance abuse treatment provider.
The substance abuse treatment provider shall notify the addictions specialist of the ongoing treatment status of the applicant or recipient.
The addictions specialist shall notify the FIP case manager if an applicant or recipient:

sub-subparagraph.text: fails to complete the assessment required under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection;
fails to sign the consent form required under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection;
is referred for appropriate substance abuse treatment;
is awaiting the availability of appropriate treatment;
fails to enroll or maintain enrollment with an available substance treatment provider or to complete the treatment protocol;
is enrolled in a treatment program; or
successfully completes treatment.

subparagraph.text: The addictions specialist shall also notify the FIP case manager regarding the ongoing treatment status of the applicant or recipient.

subsection.text: An adult or minor parent applicant or recipient who complies with the substance abuse treatment requirements of the FIP:

paragraph.text: shall receive a full temporary cash assistance benefit as long as the applicant or recipient meets the other temporary cash assistance eligibility requirements; and
may be exempt from the work activity requirements for a period of time determined by the FIP case manager in consultation with the addictions specialist.

subsection.text: An adult or minor parent applicant or recipient is not in compliance with FIP requirements if the FIP case manager receives notice from the addictions specialist that the applicant or recipient:

paragraph.text: fails to complete the screening or assessment required under subsections (b)(2) and (c)(1)(i) of this section;
fails to sign the consent form required under subsection (c)(1)(iii) of this section; or

is referred for appropriate and available substance abuse treatment by the addictions specialist but fails to enroll or to maintain active enrollment in the treatment program or complete the treatment protocol.

subsection.text: After the FIP case manager receives a notice under subsection (e) of this section, the local department shall:

paragraph.text: send a denial notice to the adult or minor parent applicant that:

subparagraph.text: states:

sub-subparagraph.text: that the applicant has not met FIP requirements;
the specific reason why the applicant is not eligible for FIP; and
that if the applicant fails to fulfill the requirements on or before the 30th work day after the application for temporary cash assistance was filed, the application is denied; and

subparagraph.text: notifies the applicant of the applicant’s right to appeal and the procedures for filing an appeal; and

paragraph.text: separately determine eligibility for medical assistance and food stamps.

subsection.text: After the FIP case manager receives a notice under subsection (e) of this section, the local department shall send a notice to the adult or minor parent recipient that:

paragraph.text: identifies the recipient who is not in compliance with FIP requirements;
states the specific reason why that recipient is not in compliance with FIP requirements; and
states that 30 days after the date of the notice:

subparagraph.text: the temporary cash assistance benefits will be reduced by that increment in cash benefits attributable to the noncompliant recipient; and
the remainder of the cash benefits for the child or children in the FIP case will be paid to a third party payee or a compliant adult recipient; and

paragraph.text: notifies the recipient of the recipient’s right to appeal and the procedures for filing an appeal.

The local department shall reduce the temporary cash assistance benefits of an adult or minor parent recipient and pay the remainder of the cash benefits to a third party payee or a compliant adult recipient as described in subsection (g) of this section, if:

subparagraph.text: the recipient fails to complete a substance abuse screening or assessment by an addictions specialist, as required under subsections (b)(2) and (c)(1)(i) of this section; or

the required screening and assessment or the results of any follow-up diagnostic testing or treatment reveal that the recipient is a substance abuser and the recipient refuses to enroll or maintain enrollment in available and appropriate substance abuse treatment.

paragraph.text: The local department shall continue to make temporary cash assistance benefits payments to a third party payee or a compliant adult recipient until the local department receives notice from the addictions specialist that the recipient is actively enrolled, as defined by the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Administration, in the appropriate substance abuse treatment indicated by the addictions specialist.

subsection.text: The local department may not deny an adult or minor parent applicant’s temporary cash assistance benefit or reduce an adult or minor parent recipient’s temporary cash assistance benefit as described under subsections (f) and (g) of this section, if the applicant or recipient:

paragraph.text: receives the screening and assessment required under subsections (b)(2) and (c)(1)(i) of this section, and the screening and assessment or the results of any follow-up diagnostic testing or treatment reveal that the applicant or recipient is a substance abuser; and
agrees to participate in appropriate substance abuse treatment, as determined by the addictions specialist, but the appropriate substance abuse treatment is not available.

subsection.text: The denial or reduction of temporary cash assistance under this section does not affect an adult or minor parent applicant or recipient’s eligibility for medical assistance and food stamps, as long as the applicant or recipient meets the medical assistance and food stamp program requirements.
Subsections (b) and (c) of this section are not intended to create an incentive for individuals to seek temporary cash assistance benefits instead of employment.
In determining a family’s eligibility for the FIP, the local department shall exclude Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits provided to an adult or child family member.
Except as limited by federal requirements, the level of temporary cash assistance, as determined by a local department, shall:

paragraph.text: be determined with due regard to the available resources, necessary expenditures, and specific conditions of a family; and
be sufficient, when added to all other income and support available to the child, to provide a child with a reasonable subsistence compatible with decency and health.

subsection.text: A recipient who obtains employment remains eligible for medical assistance for up to 12 months after the date of employment.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Governor shall provide sufficient funds in the budget to:

subparagraph.text: ensure that the value of temporary cash assistance, combined with federal food stamps, is equal to at least 61% of the State minimum living level; and
maintain the FIP at the level of the fiscal year 1997 appropriation.

paragraph.text: The funds provided under this subsection may be less than the amount required under paragraph (1) of this subsection if the Governor reports to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, on the reasons for the reduced funding for temporary cash assistance and food stamps.
This subsection does not limit the flexibility of local departments regarding the provision of services.

subsection.text: If the Secretary determines during the fiscal year that the funds available for the FIP are insufficient to make payments in accordance with the amount of assistance otherwise established by law, the Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: provide for a uniform method of adjusting individual payments;
notify the Joint Committee on Welfare Reform; and
submit emergency regulations, in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article, to implement the adjustment.

subsection.text: Effective July 1 of each year, the Department shall make available for reallocation within its budget any savings the Department anticipates from funds appropriated for the FIP during the current fiscal year as a result of:

paragraph.text: caseload reductions; or
other reductions in the total amount of temporary cash assistance paid to recipients compared to the total amount of temporary cash assistance appropriated.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (e)(1) of this section, savings made available for reallocation may be used for:

paragraph.text: child care;
work activities;
welfare avoidance grants;
drug treatment for targeted recipients;
transportation;
emergency funds for applicants and recipients;
administration to the extent that additional administrative costs are required to effectively implement the FIP; or
any other direct service to applicants or recipients that the Secretary and the local department consider appropriate to further the purposes of this subtitle.
Savings shall be made available for reallocation as follows:

subparagraph.text: 10% of the savings to the operating costs for one or more of the following:

sub-subparagraph.text: demonstration projects established under § 5-317 of this subtitle;
second chance homes not subject to the restrictions of § 12 of Chapter 351 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1996; or
demonstration projects to empirically evaluate strategies to reduce the incidence of nonmarital births in the State;

subparagraph.text: 45% of the savings to local departments, in accordance with the savings achieved by each local department, for the purposes authorized under subsection (d) of this section; and
45% of the savings for the purposes authorized under subsection (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, any savings allocated under this subsection that remain unexpended at the end of a fiscal year may be carried over into the next fiscal year.
The Secretary shall establish demonstration projects through grants to:

subparagraph.text: nonprofit organizations;
local education agencies;
local management boards;
local health departments;
religious organizations; and
institutions of higher education.

paragraph.text: The entities listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall jointly develop proposals for demonstration projects under this section with local departments.
At least one of the demonstration projects under this section shall be located in a county other than the two counties with the largest numbers of FIP recipients.
The Secretary shall award grants for demonstration projects under this section through a competitive bid process that includes:

subparagraph.text: the issuance of a request for proposals; and
the establishment of an evaluation panel to review competing proposals and to make a recommendation to the Secretary concerning which proposals have the greatest programmatic and financial merit.
Not more than 50% of the funds allocated for demonstration projects under this section may be allocated to a single demonstration project.
The funds allocated for demonstration projects under this section are incentive funds over and above any transfer of FIP benefits to a third party payee.

paragraph.text: Funds allocable to demonstration projects under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall, if feasible, be used for demonstration projects in the counties that generated the savings reallocated to demonstration projects under § 5-316(e) of this subtitle.

When awarding grants under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall give priority in funding for at least 20% of the funds allocated to demonstration projects under this section to regional proposals from two or more counties in the State.
Funds allocated to demonstration projects under this section may not be used in the furtherance of sectarian religious instruction or worship.

subsection.text: In the request for proposals issued under subsection (b)(1)(i) of this section, the Secretary shall include requirements that:

paragraph.text: applicants specify what goods or services, or both, they will provide to participants; and
each demonstration project:

subparagraph.text: complement the local department FIP Plan; and
address specific, unmet local needs and barriers that prevent families from meeting the requirements of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In addition to the demonstration projects funded under subsection (b) of this section, the Secretary shall encourage and facilitate demonstration projects that are supported through:

paragraph.text: the voluntary transfer of temporary cash assistance and food stamp benefits to the demonstration project;
the transfer of administrative costs from the local department; and
any nonstate funds available to the project.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Children of current or former recipients” has the meaning stated in § 5–304 of this subtitle.
“Former recipient” has the meaning stated in § 5–304 of this subtitle.
“Foster youth” has the meaning stated in § 5–304 of this subtitle.
“Obligor” has the meaning stated in § 10–101 of the Family Law Article.

In cooperation with the local directors, the Secretary shall establish a job skills enhancement program to provide newly employed current and former recipients, children of current or former recipients, foster youth, and obligors with training to:

subparagraph.text: enhance existing job–related skills;
gain additional or alternative job skills; or
learn interpersonal, communication, and other related skills.

paragraph.text: The job skills enhancement program shall be established in at least three counties, one of which shall be located in Western Maryland, Southern Maryland, or the Eastern Shore.

subsection.text: The job skills enhancement program shall:

paragraph.text: target unskilled and semiskilled former and current recipients, children of current or former recipients, foster youth, and obligors who are newly employed in entry–level positions that have limited potential for advancement beyond entry–level; or

target job training for former and current recipients, children of current or former recipients, foster youth, and obligors for employment in energy and environmental industries and construction, including:

subparagraph.text: the energy–efficient building, construction, and retrofits industries;
the renewable electric power industry;
the energy efficient and advanced drive train vehicle industry;
the biofuels industry;
the deconstruction and materials use industries;
the energy assessment industry serving the residential, commercial, or industrial sector;
the manufacturing industry that produces sustainable products using environmentally sustainable processes and materials;
the brownfields remediation industry;
the state of the art septic upgrades and sewage treatment industry;
environmental restoration, including stream restoration, reforestation, invasive removal, and acid mine drainage;
state of the art storm water installation and retrofits;
agriculture conservation practices;
the green roof industry and green roof maintenance industry; and
sustainable landscaping.

paragraph.text: Participation in the job skills enhancement program shall be voluntary.
Individuals participating in the job skills enhancement program shall sign a training agreement with the local department.

subsection.text: To be eligible to participate in the job skills enhancement program, an individual shall:

subparagraph.text: have been a recipient during the 36 months before beginning participation in the job skills enhancement program; or
be a former recipient, a child of a current or former recipient, a foster youth, or obligor;

paragraph.text: have been employed in entry–level employment for at least 6 months before beginning participation in the job skills enhancement program;
provide employer validation or other documentation of employment status;
have limited job skills; and
have limited opportunity for advancement in the individual’s current employment.

subsection.text: The local department shall contract for training services to be provided under the job skills enhancement program, as provided in § 5–306 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The local department may work with businesses to train and place current and former recipients, children of current or former recipients, foster youth, and obligors in positions that meet the requirements of paragraph (2) of this subsection.
Participating businesses shall:

subparagraph.text: provide employment with benefits paid to employees;
provide employment that has a defined career path;
demonstrate the active involvement and financial commitment of the business; and
provide a match with cash or in–kind contributions on at least a one–to–one basis.

paragraph.text: At the discretion of the Secretary and in consultation with the local director, the job skills enhancement program shall be administered by the local department or through the State workforce investment area system under the Workforce Investment Act.
The Administrator of the program under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: manage each participant’s training plan;
maintain a database of appropriate training vendors; and
compile necessary fiscal reports on the job skills enhancement program.

subsection.text: In addition to any other funds available to fund the job skills enhancement program, the Secretary shall attempt to access funds available to the State under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act and any other funds designed to reduce energy use and global warming emissions that would be available for job training in the industries listed under subsection (c)(2) of this section.
In this section, “demonstration site” means a site that the Secretary selects in consultation with the local director.
The Secretary may establish a FIP demonstration site in not more than six jurisdictions.
Notwithstanding any other law, the local director shall appoint a director of the FIP established in a demonstration site who shall report directly to the local director.

Notwithstanding any other law, the Secretary has sole authority to approve demonstration site plans that will govern FIP functions in a demonstration site, including the authority to approve demonstration site plans that will:

paragraph.text: assist families that have an employable parent toward a lasting exit from temporary cash assistance;
ensure that individuals and families receive appropriate benefits;
reduce errors in the administration of FIP;
place temporary cash assistance recipients in employment in which their earnings will likely increase; and
improve the types of employment and employment retention rates of existing and former recipients.

subsection.text: The local director shall:

paragraph.text: develop a demonstration site plan for submittal to the Secretary for approval that will detail its:

subparagraph.text: programmatic structure, including any programmatic changes;
organizational structure, including any organizational changes;
pay incentive structure and criteria for the award of pay incentives;
measurable performance criteria and how these relate to the incentive structure; and
target performance criteria;

paragraph.text: implement the plan as approved; and
report to the Department on the progress achieved in the demonstration site.

subsection.text: The proper operation of the demonstration site and the achievement of the target performance criteria shall be an element of the local director’s performance evaluation.
The Secretary shall establish a performance incentive program to provide pay incentives for employees in a demonstration site.
The Secretary’s powers under this section shall be construed liberally.
In cooperation with local directors, the Secretary shall establish a mentoring program for former recipients.

paragraph.text: The mentoring program may include FIP caseworkers in local departments who volunteer to be mentors.
The Department may contract with other entities under § 5-306 of this subtitle to acquire mentors for former recipients.

subsection.text: Mentoring may include:

paragraph.text: providing assistance to resolve workplace problems;
providing workplace adjustment assistance;
job coaching;
providing assistance to develop life skills;
counseling and tutoring; and
any other activities that will help former recipients through the first months that they no longer receive temporary cash assistance.

subsection.text: To be eligible to participate in the mentoring program, an individual shall:

paragraph.text: have been a recipient in the previous 6 months;
have been employed; and
have a demonstrated need and desire for assistance in acquiring and maintaining the skills necessary for a lasting exit from temporary cash assistance.

subsection.text: Program participation may not exceed 6 months.
The Secretary may arrange to provide pay or other types of incentives to employees who volunteer to mentor former recipients.
The Secretary’s powers under this section shall be construed liberally.
Any assistance granted under this subtitle is subject to future amendment or repeal of this subtitle.
A recipient is not entitled to compensation if the recipient’s assistance is affected by amendment or repeal of this subtitle.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Applicant” means an individual who applies for assistance under this part.
“Assistance” means:

paragraph.text: cash payments to a recipient; and
payments necessary for supplementary services for a recipient, including:

subparagraph.text: the recipient’s funeral expenses as provided in § 5-415 of this subtitle; and
placement of the recipient in a suitable home or institution if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the recipient lacks a legal guardian or other person legally responsible for the recipient’s support; and
the recipient consents.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Public Assistance to Adults Program.
“Recipient” means an individual who receives, or has received, assistance under this part.
There is a State funded Public Assistance to Adults Program in the Administration.
The Program shall be:

paragraph.text: in effect in each county; and
administered by the local departments in accordance with regulations that the Administration adopts.

subsection.text: A resident of the State is eligible for assistance under this part if the resident:

paragraph.text: lacks sufficient income or benefits to maintain a reasonable subsistence compatible with decency and health; and

subparagraph.text: is eligible for or receives cash benefits under Title XVI of the federal Social Security Act; or
is aged, blind, or disabled as defined under Title XVI of the federal Social Security Act and, but for income, would receive cash benefits under that title.

subsection.text: An applicant may not assign or transfer property to establish eligibility for assistance under this part during the 3 years before:

paragraph.text: filing an application for assistance; or
receiving assistance.

subsection.text: An application for assistance under this part shall be made:

paragraph.text: to the local department of the county where the applicant resides; and
in the form and manner that the Administration requires.

subsection.text: Whenever a local department receives an application for assistance under this part, the local department shall make a record of:

paragraph.text: the circumstances of the applicant;
the facts supporting the application; and
any other information that the Administration requires by regulation.

The local department shall determine an amount of assistance that is sufficient, when added to all other income and support available to a recipient, to provide the recipient with a reasonable subsistence compatible with decency and health.
In determining the amount of assistance, the local department shall consider the recipient’s available resources and necessary expenditures and the conditions existing for the recipient.

subsection.text: In determining the amount of assistance, the local department shall consider support from children as a potential resource and evaluate the amount of the support and its availability to the recipient, in accordance with regulations that the Administration adopts.
The local department shall:

paragraph.text: determine:

subparagraph.text: whether an applicant is eligible for assistance under this part; and
in accordance with regulations that the Administration adopts, the amount of the assistance and the date on which the assistance will begin; and

paragraph.text: notify the applicant of its decision.

subsection.text: Assistance shall be paid to the applicant monthly or as the Administration otherwise determines.

If the funds available are insufficient to make payments in accordance with the amount of assistance established to be needed, the Administration shall adopt regulations to provide for a uniform method of adjusting individual payments.

paragraph.text: Assistance granted under this part may not be transferred or assigned.
Assistance paid or payable under this part is not subject to:

subparagraph.text: execution;
levy;
attachment;
garnishment;
other legal process; or
the operation of any bankruptcy or insolvency law.

paragraph.text: The local department shall reconsider all assistance granted under this part as frequently as the regulations of the Administration require.

The amount of assistance may be changed or assistance may be canceled if, after any further investigation the local department considers necessary or the Administration requires, the local department or the Administration finds that the recipient’s circumstances have altered sufficiently to warrant the change or cancellation.
A recipient shall notify the local department immediately if, while receiving assistance, the recipient receives property or income in excess of the amount stated in the application for assistance.
After an investigation, depending on the circumstances, the local department may:

subparagraph.text: cancel the assistance; or
change the amount of assistance.

paragraph.text: Assistance paid before the recipient received the property or income that exceeds the recipient’s need may be recovered by the local department as a debt due.
The net amount recovered shall be divided between the State and county in proportion to the amount of assistance paid by each.
When a recipient dies:

subparagraph.text: the total amount of assistance paid under this part shall be allowed as a claim against the estate; and
the net amount recovered shall be divided between the State and county in proportion to the amount of assistance paid by each.

paragraph.text: The claim may not be enforced against real estate occupied by the recipient’s surviving spouse or dependents.

subsection.text: An applicant or recipient may appeal to the Administration if the local department:

paragraph.text: does not act on an application within a reasonable time;
denies an application wholly or partly; or
modifies or cancels a grant of assistance.
The appeal shall be filed in the manner and form that the Administration requires.
The Administration shall give the applicant or recipient reasonable notice and an opportunity for a hearing on the appeal.
On its own motion, the Administration may:

subparagraph.text: review any decision of a local department; and
consider an application on which the local department has not made a decision within a reasonable time.

paragraph.text: The Administration:

subparagraph.text: may make any additional investigation it considers necessary; and
shall make any decision on the granting of assistance and the amount of assistance it considers justified in accordance with this part.

paragraph.text: On request, the Administration shall give an applicant or recipient affected by a decision made under paragraph (2) of this subsection reasonable notice and an opportunity for a hearing.
A decision of the Administration under this section is final and binding on the local department.
The local department shall comply with a decision of the Administration under this section.

section.text: The Administration shall:

paragraph.text: supervise the administration of the Program under this part by the local departments;
adopt regulations necessary or desirable to carry out this part, including regulations to:

subparagraph.text: establish eligibility requirements and any other requirements not set forth in this part; and
establish standards for the amount of assistance a recipient may receive under this part;

paragraph.text: prescribe the form of and supply to the local departments any forms the Administration considers necessary and desirable; and
take any other action necessary or desirable to carry out this part.

section.text: Each local department shall:

paragraph.text: administer this part in its county in accordance with the regulations the Administration adopts; and
report to the Administration as the Administration directs.

subsection.text: Except in connection with a criminal proceeding brought under this part, a person may not charge or receive a fee from an applicant, recipient, or any other person:

paragraph.text: with respect to an application under this part; or
to represent an applicant or recipient in any proceeding under this part.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
Any assistance granted under this part is subject to future repeal or amendment of this part.
A recipient is not entitled to compensation if the recipient’s assistance is affected by repeal or amendment of this part.

paragraph.text: A local department may pay the reasonable funeral expenses of a decedent who was a:

subparagraph.text: recipient of public assistance, including temporary cash assistance or public assistance to adults; or
State resident receiving Supplemental Security Income under Title XVI of the Social Security Act.

paragraph.text: The funeral expenses paid by the local department may not exceed $900.

subsection.text: A local department may not pay funeral expenses under this section unless:

paragraph.text: each person legally responsible for the support of the decedent is unable to pay the expenses; and
other resources, including available death benefits of the estate, are insufficient to pay the expenses.

subsection.text: Payments provided in accordance with this section shall be charged to State funds.
The Department may implement a food stamp program in accordance with the federal Food Stamp Act.
The State shall bear the nonfederal portion of the administrative costs of the food stamp program for each county.
Each local department shall administer the food stamp program:

paragraph.text: under the supervision and control of the Department; and
in accordance with the regulations of the Department and federal law.

section.text: Except as provided in § 5-503 of this subtitle, if any provision of this subtitle conflicts with any federal law, the federal law shall prevail.
Subject to the State budget, the Department shall provide food stamp benefits to a legal immigrant who:

paragraph.text: is a minor;
is ineligible for federally funded food stamp benefits because of immigration status;
meets all other food stamp program eligibility requirements; and
meets any other requirements of the State.

subsection.text: A person may not sell or purchase food stamp program benefits unless otherwise authorized by law.
A person may not knowingly buy or sell merchandise that has been purchased with food stamp program benefits.
If the value of the money or goods involved is $1,000 or more, a person who violates this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction:

paragraph.text: is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $10,000 or both; and
shall make full restitution of the money or goods unlawfully received or perform community service, as determined by the court.

subsection.text: If the value of the money or goods involved is less than $1,000, a person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction:

paragraph.text: is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
shall make full restitution of the money or goods unlawfully received or perform community service, as determined by the court.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Energy emergency” means a lack of fuel or the imminent discontinuation of energy services supplied by a fuel vendor or utility vendor that will endanger health, safety, or welfare.
“Fuel vendor” means a person that distributes, transports, produces, or offers for sale coal products, fuel oil, kerosene, bottled gas, propane, or wood for fuel use or consumption in the State.
“Office” means the Office of Home Energy Programs.
“Program” means the Energy Assistance Program.
“Utility vendor” means a person that distributes, transports, or produces natural gas or electricity for use or consumption in the State.

section.text: There is an Office of Home Energy Programs in the Administration.
The purpose of the Office is to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Office may employ a staff.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the employees of the Office are subject to the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

section.text: The Office exercises its authority, duties, and functions under any State law subject to the authority of the Secretary under any State law.

paragraph.text: The Office shall maintain liaison with:

subparagraph.text: the United States Department of Health and Human Services;
local government units concerned with energy programs;
citizens’ groups;
utility vendors and major fuel vendors in the State; and
any other state, federal, and local units.

paragraph.text: The Office shall:

subparagraph.text: consult with and advise the local entities described in paragraph (1) of this subsection regarding their energy assistance programs;
work at all levels of government to carry out this subtitle; and
consult with all utility vendors and major fuel vendors in the State when developing and implementing the Program.

subsection.text: The Office shall:

paragraph.text: collect and assemble information relating to energy assistance available from other units of the State and federal governments;
disseminate information to further energy assistance;
identify all utility vendors and major fuel vendors in the State and attempt to obtain their voluntary cooperation with the Program;

establish and maintain a State information service that utilizes a toll–free telephone number to provide the public with information about the Program and the location of the nearest local energy assistance office; and
establish a mechanism for monitoring the effectiveness of the Program to determine whether eligible households are aware of and have access to a local energy assistance office.
Consistent with this subtitle and other applicable laws, the Office may enter into contracts or assume any other function necessary to carry out this subtitle.
The Office may enter into contracts for any study or research activity that is necessary and proper.
The Office shall:

subparagraph.text: carry out an energy emergency crisis intervention program to prevent low–income households, including the near poor, the elderly, households with children, and those on fixed incomes from experiencing danger to health or survival as a result of an energy emergency;
establish intake procedures for those experiencing an energy emergency;
establish guidelines for the income and program eligibility of applicants; and
identify local public or private agencies to administer the crisis intervention program.
The Office shall make payments to fuel vendors and utility vendors that have provided service to persons qualifying for the crisis intervention program.
The amount of assistance shall be based on need.

paragraph.text: The Office shall carry out one or more fuel and utility assistance programs to make payments on behalf of qualified households to defray fuel and utility costs.
The Office shall determine program and income eligibility guidelines.
The amount of assistance shall be based on need.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Energy Assistance Program Act”.

subsection.text: In this section, “resident” means an individual who resides in this State on the date the individual applies for public assistance.

Subject to § 5-314 of this title and as authorized under 21 U.S.C. § 862a(d)(1), the State removes itself from the application of § 115 of the federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Act of 1996 to allow the Department to provide temporary cash assistance and food stamps to a resident who has been convicted of a felony involving the possession, use, or distribution of a controlled dangerous substance.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section, if a resident applying for temporary cash assistance or food stamps has been convicted of a felony involving the possession, use, or distribution of a controlled dangerous substance after August 22, 1996, the resident is subject to testing for substance abuse, as provided by the Department, and to treatment as required under § 5-314 of this title for 2 years, beginning on the date of application, to the extent authorized under federal law.

Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section, if a resident receiving temporary cash assistance or food stamps is found to be in violation of §§ 5-602 through 5-609, § 5-612, or § 5-613 of the Criminal Law Article, or 21 U.S.C. § 841, the resident is:

subparagraph.text: ineligible for temporary cash assistance or food stamps for 1 year after the date of the conviction; and
subject to testing for substance abuse, as provided by the Department, and to treatment as required under § 5-314 of this title, for 2 years beginning on the later of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date the individual is released from incarceration;
the date the individual completes any term of probation; or
the date the individual completes any term of parole or mandatory supervision.

paragraph.text: An applicant or recipient who fails to comply with the testing required under this subsection or the treatment required under § 5-314 of this title or who tests positive for the abuse of controlled dangerous substances is subject to the sanctions provided under § 5-314 of this title.

In consultation with the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, the Secretary shall adopt regulations to establish the testing methods and procedures, consistent with § 5-314 of this title, to be required by the Department under this subsection, including the intervals of testing and methods required.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Administration, a local department, or any other unit may not decrease the monetary amount of assistance received by any recipient of public assistance before the implementation of a system of flat grant payments, solely as a result of the implementation of the system.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Delinquent tenant” means a tenant of public housing who is 30 or more days delinquent in paying the tenant’s full monthly rent to a public housing authority.
“Public housing” means a dwelling unit owned, leased, or managed by a public housing authority.
“Public housing authority” means a public corporation created under Division II of the Housing and Community Development Article or the public corporation’s designee.

subsection.text: If a recipient of temporary cash assistance is a delinquent tenant, the Administration, at the request of the public housing authority, shall:

paragraph.text: deduct the amount of the tenant’s rent from the tenant’s monthly assistance payments each month;
pay the amount deducted from the tenant’s monthly assistance payments to the public housing authority or the public housing authority’s authorized agent; and
forward the remaining amount of the monthly assistance payments to the tenant.

If a court establishes an escrow account under § 8-211 of the Real Property Article or a parallel provision of public local law for a tenancy covered under subsection (b) of this section, the public housing authority shall notify the Administration of the court action.

On notice under paragraph (1) of this subsection or on certification by an attorney of record representing the delinquent tenant in the court action that an order has been issued to establish an escrow account, the Administration shall pay rent to the court as long as the order is in effect.
Any notice under paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection shall include a list of all addresses covered by the court action.
The public housing authority shall notify the Administration when the court action has been resolved.

subsection.text: The Department may request and obtain from a fiduciary institution doing business in the State any financial records that the Department determines are necessary to verify or confirm an individual’s eligibility or ineligibility for public assistance.

subparagraph.text: The Department shall adopt regulations governing procedures for requesting, obtaining, and examining financial records that the Department determines are necessary to verify or confirm an individual’s eligibility or ineligibility for public assistance.
The regulations shall include reimbursement schedules necessary to compensate fiduciary institutions for complying with this section.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall notify a fiduciary institution of the officers or employees of the Department who are authorized to request and receive financial records from the fiduciary institution.
An individual authorized to receive information under this section may not disclose any personally identifiable information obtained or maintained under this section.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Public assistance” means any assistance described in § 8-503 of the Criminal Law Article.
“Fraud” has the meaning stated in § 8-501 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: Each applicant for or recipient of public assistance shall:

paragraph.text: read or have read to the individual a statement of the conduct that constitutes fraud; and
sign the statement to acknowledge that the individual understands that the penalties for fraud under § 8-503 of the Criminal Law Article are:

subparagraph.text: imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
restitution.

section.text: The local department shall place a duplicate photo identification print in the case file of a public assistance recipient whenever a photo identification card is issued to the recipient.

subsection.text: The Administration shall make every effort to recoup overpayments made to recipients that the State is authorized to recoup under federal law.
The Administration shall establish an administrative procedure, in accordance with federal law, to be followed when the Administration has reason to believe that an overpayment has been made.

section.text: The Administration may:

paragraph.text: accept any federal funds or commodities;
manage and dispose of any federal funds or commodities as required by federal law; and
apply the federal Social Security Act or any other federal law relating to public assistance to the benefit of the State.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Human Resources.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Human Resources.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Applicant” means an entity that applies for a grant under this part.
“Distribution organization” means a nonprofit entity that distributes food or equipment to emergency food organizations.

paragraph.text: “Emergency food organization” means a nonprofit entity that provides emergency food services.
“Emergency food organization” includes an organization that operates:

subparagraph.text: a soup kitchen; or
a food pantry.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Statewide Nutrition-Assistance Equipment Program.

section.text: There is a Statewide Nutrition-Assistance Equipment Program administered by the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to provide funding to distribution organizations to enable the distribution organizations and emergency food organizations to obtain necessary equipment.
In addition to any other responsibilities for administering the Program, the responsibilities of the Department include:

paragraph.text: designing and implementing an ongoing outreach and publicity campaign to achieve the widest possible dissemination of information about the Program to:

subparagraph.text: potential applicants; and
nutrition advocacy groups in the State;

paragraph.text: receiving and reviewing applications for funding; and
allocating funds for approved applications in accordance with this part.

subsection.text: When reviewing and awarding grants under this part, the Department shall consider:

paragraph.text: the equitable distribution of funds across all geographical regions of the State;
the adequacy of existing distribution organizations in the region served or intended to be served by the applicant;
the estimated population to be served by the applicant;
the applicant’s level of experience in operating a distribution organization; and
the amount of funding and other resources available to the applicant.

The Department may not release funds to a grantee under this part until the grantee establishes that the grantee has obtained matching resources or a commitment for matching resources that equals at least 50% of the grant amount.
The matching resources may be in the form of cash or an in-kind equivalent acceptable to the Department.

section.text: The Department shall report annually to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the activities of the Program, including:

paragraph.text: financial reports;
distribution of funds;
community participation; and
the overall effectiveness of the Program in fulfilling its stated purpose.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administering agency” means an entity that the Department approves in accordance with § 6-414 of this subtitle to administer the Program at the county level.

paragraph.text: “Emergency food provider” means a nonprofit organization or an organization operated by a local government that provides food at no charge to needy individuals.
“Emergency food provider” includes:

subparagraph.text: a soup kitchen; and
a food pantry.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Maryland Emergency Food Program.

section.text: Subject to the State budget, there is a Maryland Emergency Food Program in the Department.

subsection.text: The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: provide funding to assist emergency food providers in purchasing food for needy individuals;
encourage needy individuals to become self-sufficient; and
distribute information on the State’s earned income tax credit established under § 10-704 of the Tax - General Article.

subsection.text: When feasible and cost effective, food purchased under the Program shall be produced, grown, and harvested in the State.
The Department shall manage the Program.
Each administering agency shall:

paragraph.text: provide emergency food providers with information about the Program, including Program guidelines and fund availability;
accept and process requests for funding assistance from emergency food providers; and
allocate funding to emergency food providers based on the procedures approved in the administering agency’s grant application under § 6-413 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An emergency food provider that receives a Program grant shall:

paragraph.text: use the grant to purchase food for distribution to needy individuals;

as a condition of distributing food, provide to needy individuals information, developed in collaboration with the Department, that encourages self-sufficiency consistent with the goals of the Family Investment Program established under Title 5, Subtitle 3 of this article;
distribute information on the State’s earned income tax credit established under § 10-704 of the Tax - General Article; and
submit a report to the Department and the administering agency detailing how the grant was used and how many units of service were provided.
No more than 5% of the Program’s budget may be used to cover administrative costs of the Program.
All remaining funding shall be allocated for food purchase only.
Program funds may not be used for equipment or other capital expenditures.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: adopt a formula and qualifications for allocating Program funds to the counties based on county-wide statistics for:

subparagraph.text: the number of families living in poverty;
the unemployment rate; and
the number of families receiving food stamps;

paragraph.text: submit annually to the State Advisory Council on Hunger a report detailing:

subparagraph.text: the total appropriations for the Program for the current and prior fiscal years, including the amount allocated for administrative costs, the amount allocated to each administering agency, and the amount allocated to emergency food providers in each county; and
how many units of service were provided in each county; and

paragraph.text: notify each county through the administering agency of the availability of Program funds under item (1) of this subsection.
Each administering agency shall apply to the Department for a Program grant.
The application shall include the procedures that the administering agency will use to:

subparagraph.text: notify emergency food providers of the availability of Program grants;
approve emergency food providers as recipients of Program grants; and
allocate Program grants among approved emergency food providers.

subsection.text: Before an administering agency may receive a Program grant, the Department must approve the application.
The Department shall adopt regulations to govern the selection and approval of an administering agency for each county.
The regulations adopted under this section shall include:

paragraph.text: criteria to ensure that the selected administering agency has adequate internal controls over cash receipts, materials, supplies, and inventories; and
a definition of “units of service” that shall be used to track Program utilization.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Advisory Board” means the Governor’s Advisory Board on Homelessness.
“Homeless individual” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: is in need of housing or emergency shelter and proper nutrition;
cannot be placed immediately in another available housing, nutrition, and service program; and
is a resident of the State when the individual makes an application for housing.

subsection.text: “Housing crisis” means a situation involving a family or individual who is:

paragraph.text: threatened with the immediate loss of housing or other shelter;
without resources to avoid an impending eviction; or
otherwise at risk of becoming homeless.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Shelter, Nutrition, and Service Program for Homeless Individuals and Families.

section.text: The General Assembly finds and declares that:

paragraph.text: an increasing number of individuals and families in the State are homeless and lack proper nutrition and adequate services;
current State-operated programs do not adequately address these problems; and
as a result, there is a lack of quality emergency public and private housing, nutrition, and service programs available for these individuals and families.

section.text: The Governor may establish a shelter, nutrition, and service program for homeless individuals and families.
The purposes of the Program are to provide facilities or programs that offer and provide:

paragraph.text: crisis and transition shelter, proper nutrition, and adequate services to homeless individuals and families, which may include linkage to multiple service components, centralized decision making regarding placement, case management, transportation, and follow-up services; and
services to prevent individuals and families in a housing crisis from becoming homeless.

section.text: There is an Advisory Board on Homelessness.

subsection.text: The Advisory Board consists of two members from each congressional district in the State appointed by the Governor.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 2 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Advisory Board on October 1, 2007.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

paragraph.text: From among its members, the Advisory Board annually shall elect a chair.
The manner of the election of a chair shall be as the Advisory Board determines.

subsection.text: The Advisory Board may employ a staff and make other expenditures in accordance with the State budget.
A majority of the members then serving on the Advisory Board is a quorum.
The Advisory Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Advisory Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Advisory Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: The Advisory Board shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Department on the adoption of regulations to design and administer the Program;
coordinate and monitor the operation of the Program;
propose annually to the Department a budget and a funding request for the Program;
advise the Department on:

subparagraph.text: a plan to serve homeless individuals;
the distribution of funds;
the effectiveness of programs; and
the needs of the homeless;

paragraph.text: make recommendations to the Department on the allocation of any available federal funds, State funds, foundation grants, and private donations to establish, administer, and operate shelter, nutrition, and service programs for homeless individuals and families;

make recommendations to the Department on the allocation of funds to the areas of the State considering unmet needs, the number of homeless individuals and families in those areas, proximity to similar services, availability of alternate sources of funds, and other relevant factors; and
report annually to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the activities of the Program, including:

subparagraph.text: financial reports;
Advisory Board actions;
distribution of funds; and
service successes and failures.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: contract with nonprofit organizations to operate the Program;
seek the recommendations of the Advisory Board about policy determinations, the allocation of funds, and the development of a plan to serve homeless individuals and families;
allocate any available federal funds and State funds to establish, administer, and operate shelter, nutrition, and service programs for homeless individuals and families;
allocate funds to the areas of the State, considering unmet needs and the number of homeless individuals and families in those areas;
establish a housing counselor and aftercare program to assist families and individuals in obtaining and maintaining permanent housing;
establish and implement a homelessness prevention program to provide services to families and individuals in a housing crisis, which may include:

subparagraph.text: case management services;
counseling to detect households at risk of becoming homeless;
training on budgeting and other life skills;
education about tenants’ rights and responsibilities; and
cash assistance;

paragraph.text: establish uniform reporting criteria for providers of services to homeless individuals and families under this part;
collect regional data on the number of homeless individuals and families that receive services under this part; and
make recommendations on the resources necessary to provide adequate programs.
The Department shall report annually to the Governor on the extent of homelessness during the preceding year.

The Department shall submit a report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the effectiveness of the homelessness prevention program in preventing families and individuals from becoming homeless.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations, with the advice and recommendations of the Advisory Board, to govern the implementation and evaluation of the Program under this part.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Client” means a woman who is in need of housing and is not eligible for other available housing services.
“Program” means the Homeless Women - Crisis Shelter Home Program.

section.text: The General Assembly finds and declares that:

paragraph.text: an increasing number of women in the State are homeless;
homeless women have been ignored by State units;
current State-operated programs do not adequately address the problem; and
as a result, there is a lack of quality emergency public or private housing available for homeless women.

subsection.text: There is a Homeless Women - Crisis Shelter Home Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to provide crisis shelter homes, meals, and counseling to clients.
At least one crisis shelter home shall be located in a major population center of the State to facilitate the use of the shelter by clients living in the region surrounding the shelter.

section.text: The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene may not use a shelter home as part of its discharge service plan.

subsection.text: A shelter home:

paragraph.text: shall provide clients with a temporary residence of not more than 12 continuous weeks and necessary counseling to link clients to appropriate community services to stabilize the clients’ living conditions;
shall accept, from the police and other referral sources in the community, clients for temporary shelter;
shall conform to applicable State and local fire codes, health codes, and zoning ordinances; and
is subject to the regulations adopted by the Department.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: establish standards of care and admission policies for shelter homes;
monitor the operation of the shelter homes; and
annually evaluate the effectiveness of the shelter homes.

subsection.text: The Department may contract with private nonprofit organizations to operate the Program.

section.text: Clients shall have cooperative responsibility for housekeeping duties in a shelter home.
The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene shall:

paragraph.text: give a client evaluated by a shelter home priority access, as appropriate, to an institution that the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene supervises; and
supply appropriate mental health services to the client.

section.text: Housing may not be provided under this part to an applicant for housing who is not a resident of the State at the time the application is made.

subsection.text: Funds to operate the Program shall be as provided in the State budget.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations that set fees for services provided by the Program.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Community services” means household and personal services provided for an elderly individual under the direction and supervision of an appropriate social services or health agency.
“Community services” includes assistance with:

subparagraph.text: meal preparation and planning;
home-delivered meal services;
dressing;
shopping;
visits to health, recreational, and shopping facilities;
transportation and personal escort services;
light housekeeping; and
personal medical and nursing care related to the provision of community services.

subsection.text: “Elderly individual” means an individual at least 65 years old and the individual’s spouse, regardless of the spouse’s age.

It is the policy of the State that elderly individuals in the State should have access to a comprehensive range of community services to enable them to remain in their own homes or other independent living arrangements consistent with their desires, abilities, and safety.

It is the intent of the General Assembly that the community services provided under this subtitle shall be available to all elderly individuals, but that those elderly individuals who are financially able to do so shall pay all or a portion of the costs of the community services.

section.text: With the advice, cooperation, and assistance of the Department of Aging and the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, the Department shall administer a system of community services to serve as an effective alternative to inappropriate institutional care for elderly individuals.
To carry out the system of community services required under this part, the Department or its designee shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations, including standards and means for reimbursement from elderly individuals financially able to pay for all or part of the services provided;
monitor continuously the effectiveness of the system and perform evaluative research through the Department of Aging;
contract, where feasible and desirable, with governmental units, private nonprofit organizations, and volunteer groups to provide community services and group nutritional dining services;
provide funds to train individuals to perform community services and for administrative costs of the system; and
use, to the extent available, grants from federal, State, and other public or private sources to fund the system.

subsection.text: To the extent possible, the Department shall train and utilize elderly individuals to perform community services.
Elderly individuals compensated for performing community services are not subject to the State Personnel Management System or any merit system of a political subdivision.
The Department has sole authority for determining all conditions of employment and rates of compensation.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“CARE Program” means the Certified Adult Residential Environment Program.

paragraph.text: “Individual with a disability” means an adult who requires a supportive housing arrangement to reside in the community because of a physical, medical, or mental disability.
“Individual with a disability” does not include an adult whose disability is so severe or complex as to require specialized professional intervention as part of the supportive housing arrangement.

subsection.text: “Supportive housing arrangement” means a housing arrangement that provides an individual with room, board, and assistance with the activities of daily living.
The General Assembly finds and declares that:

paragraph.text: an increasing number of adults in the State are unable, because of disability, to reside in the community without a supportive housing arrangement;
many of these adults are therefore homeless, unnecessarily institutionalized, or residing in substandard housing; and
current State-operated programs do not adequately address this problem.

subsection.text: It is the policy of the State to encourage the development of affordable housing for adults who are unable to avail themselves of existing housing because of disability.
There is a CARE Program in the Department.
The purpose of the CARE Program is to provide housing and related services for individuals with disabilities.

section.text: In accordance with the State budget, the CARE Program shall provide for:

paragraph.text: the development of CARE housing;
case management to individuals with disabilities residing in CARE housing; and
supportive services for individuals with disabilities residing in CARE housing.

subsection.text: The Department of Human Resources, the Department of Education, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, and the Department of Aging shall provide appropriate ancillary services to individuals with disabilities in the CARE Program subject to programmatic eligibility and priority criteria and budgetary resources.
The Secretary of Human Resources, the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, the Secretary of Aging, and the State Superintendent of Schools shall:

paragraph.text: coordinate departmental programs to ensure that the services needed by individuals with disabilities residing in CARE housing are provided in an integrated and cost-effective manner; and
prepare and enter into a written memorandum of agreement that specifies the services to be provided by each departmental program and the integration and timing of the delivery of the services.

subsection.text: The Department may adopt regulations to carry out the CARE Program.
Eligibility for services under the CARE Program does not preclude eligibility for other services.
The CARE Program may not serve an individual with a disability who is not a resident of the State when the application for service is made.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Commission” means the Commission on Responsible Fatherhood.

subsection.text: There is a Commission on Responsible Fatherhood.
The Commission:

paragraph.text: is independent; but
is located in the Department for budgetary and administrative purposes only.

section.text: The purposes of the Commission are to:

paragraph.text: raise awareness of the problems created when a child is raised without the presence of a responsible father;
identify obstacles that impede or prevent the involvement of responsible fathers in the lives of their children; and
identify strategies that encourage responsible fatherhood.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of the following 18 members appointed by the Governor:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Budget and Management;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Secretary of Human Resources;
the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the State Superintendent of Schools;
the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office for Children;
one judge assigned to the family division of a circuit court nominated by the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals;
one member of the Senate of Maryland nominated by the President of the Senate;
one member of the House of Delegates nominated by the Speaker of the House;
three individuals with extensive programmatic or academic experience with noncustodial fathers and their children;
three individuals with an interest or expertise in matters pertaining to noncustodial fathers and their children, including representatives of community, parent, or religious groups or organizations;
two representatives of local government in areas with a significant number of noncustodial fathers; and
one noncustodial father.
The term of a member appointed under subsection (a)(10), (11), or (12) of this section is 3 years.
The term of the member appointed under subsection (a)(13) of this section is 2 years.
The terms of members appointed under subsection (a)(10), (11), (12), and (13) of this section shall be staggered as required by the terms in effect for those members on October 1, 2007.
A member who is appointed to a position with a fixed term after the term has begun shall serve only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: A member appointed under subsection (a)(1) through (6) of this section may designate in writing an alternate to represent the member and exercise the member’s power to vote.

section.text: From among the members of the Commission, the Governor shall designate a chair for a 2-year term.
