subsection.text: A majority of the members then serving on the Commission is a quorum.
The Commission shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: The Commission shall determine any necessary operating procedures, including establishing subcommittees or work groups utilizing the expertise of persons who are not members of the Commission.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the Governor, the Commission shall hire a staff director as provided in the State budget.

Subject to the advice and consent of the chair of the Commission, the staff director shall hire additional staff as provided in the State budget to perform the duties that the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.text: The staff is responsible to the Secretary solely for routine administrative purposes.
Members of the Commission may designate staff from their respective units to assist the Commission.
The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: conduct a thorough examination of the extent and implications of the absence of responsible fathers from families;
strongly advocate to ensure the development of a coordinated and comprehensive approach to the social, educational, economic, health, and legal problems of responsible fatherhood;
promote interdepartmental and public and private policy and program collaboration and coordination;
collect data and perform analyses on efforts to increase responsible fatherhood;
promote the development of statewide policies to address the issues preventing fathers from participating in raising their children;
monitor statewide progress towards reducing the number of noncustodial fathers;
promote and encourage wide community input, communication, and education regarding responsible fatherhood; and
advise local public and private agencies seeking to mobilize local efforts to promote responsible fatherhood.

subsection.text: To carry out its duties under subsection (a)(1) of this section, the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: hold hearings at which persons, organizations, and agencies with an interest in responsible fatherhood may present their views;
conduct meetings, discussions, and examinations as necessary to gather information on the laws and services relating to responsible fatherhood in this and other states;
identify and examine the limitations and problems associated with existing laws, programs, and services relating to responsible fatherhood; and
examine the financing and delivery of services relating to responsible fatherhood.

In cooperation with appropriate State and local units and in accordance with State and federal law, the Commission shall foster plans to enhance the coordination of federal- and State-funded programs and services regarding responsible fatherhood.
The Commission shall develop a coordinated comprehensive statewide plan, including estimates of necessary public and private funding, for:

subparagraph.text: increasing the participation of fathers in raising their children; and
improving services to noncustodial fathers.

paragraph.text: In accordance with the statewide plan, the Commission shall recommend to the Governor distribution of community incentive grants concerning responsible fatherhood from funds provided in the State budget for this purpose or from grants or private donations, giving priority to innovative projects that:

subparagraph.text: promote the establishment of a coordinated network of services for noncustodial fathers; and
demonstrate a high level of commitment to the project by making available nonstate funds, personnel, and facilities.

section.text: The Commission may not operate any programs or provide any direct services.
In this subtitle, “Program” means the Citizenship Promotion Program.
There is a Citizenship Promotion Program in the Department.
The purposes of the Program are:

paragraph.text: to encourage and assist eligible foreign-born residents to become naturalized citizens of the United States and active participants in the civic life of Maryland;
to increase the number and proportion of eligible foreign-born residents who become citizens of the United States; and
to encourage foreign-born residents who become citizens to be involved in our democratic institutions.

section.text: In accordance with the State budget, the Program shall:

paragraph.text: encourage eligible residents to learn English;
encourage eligible residents to become naturalized citizens of the United States;
inform eligible residents about the rights and responsibilities of citizens, the process of naturalization, and the availability of citizenship services;
make available or increase the availability of instruction in:

subparagraph.text: English as a second language;
United States history; and
citizenship preparation;

paragraph.text: make available or increase the availability of assistance in completing applications for naturalization;
establish an effective connection to nonpartisan voter registration efforts;
encourage the involvement of new citizens in democratic institutions; and
work with federal, State, and local units of government and organizations to respond to the need for citizenship services in the State.

section.text: Funding for the Program shall be as provided in the State budget, not exceeding $100,000 each year.
The Department shall adopt regulations and policies to carry out the Program.
All executive units of the State shall cooperate with the Department to implement the regulations and policies of the Program.
Each year the Department shall submit a report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly regarding the status and effectiveness of the Program.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Interagency Disabilities Board.
“Commission” means the Maryland Commission on Disabilities.
“Department” means the Department of Disabilities.
“Disability” has the meaning stated in the federal Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, 42 U.S.C. § 12102.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Disabilities.
“Unit of State government” means a department, agency, office, commission, council, or other unit in the Executive Branch of the State government.

section.text: There is a Department of Disabilities, established as a principal department of State government.

paragraph.text: With the advice and consent of the Senate, the Governor shall appoint the Secretary of Disabilities.
The Secretary is the head of the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: have extensive experience and knowledge of disability laws, legislation, and regulations, and programs for individuals with disabilities;
at a minimum, hold a bachelor’s degree; and
be an individual with a disability or appoint a deputy secretary who is an individual with a disability.

subsection.text: Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The Secretary serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is responsible directly to the Governor.
The Secretary shall advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on those matters.

subsection.text: The Secretary is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.
The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient operation of the Department.
The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the Department as necessary to fulfill the duties assigned to the Secretary.
With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a deputy secretary.
The deputy secretary shall be an individual with a disability, if the Secretary is not an individual with a disability.
The deputy secretary:

paragraph.text: serves at the pleasure of the Secretary; and
is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The deputy secretary has the duties provided by law or delegated by the Secretary.
In accordance with the State budget, the Secretary may employ a staff.
Unless otherwise provided by law, the Secretary shall appoint and remove all staff in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
The Secretary may review any personnel action taken by any unit in the Department.
The Attorney General is the legal adviser to the Department.
The Attorney General shall assign to the Department the number of assistant Attorneys General authorized by law to be assigned to the Department.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall designate one of the assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department as counsel to the Department and may not reassign that individual without consulting with the Secretary.
The counsel to the Department shall have only the following duties:

subparagraph.text: to give the legal aid, advice, and counsel required by the Secretary and any other official of the Department;
to supervise the other assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department; and
to perform for the Department the duties that the Attorney General assigns.

paragraph.text: The counsel shall perform the duties under paragraph (2) of this subsection subject to the control and supervision of the Attorney General.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations for the Department and its units.
The Secretary may adopt regulations necessary to carry out the provisions of law that are within the jurisdiction of the Secretary.
The Secretary is responsible for the budget of the Department.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the Secretary shall pay all money collected by the Department under this subtitle into the General Fund of the State.

subparagraph.text: Before publication in the Maryland Register, the Secretary shall review new or proposed changes to regulations submitted by a unit of State government that relate to the provision of resources and services to individuals with disabilities.
The regulations shall include an assessment that describes the impact of the proposed regulations on individuals with disabilities.

paragraph.text: Before implementation, the Secretary shall review new or proposed changes to policies, programs, or services submitted by a unit of State government that relate to the provision of resources and services to individuals with disabilities.
The Secretary shall review, coordinate, and concur with any application for federal aid, waivers, or grants that is:

subparagraph.text: specific to services for individuals with disabilities; and
submitted by or through any unit of State government.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise prohibited by law, the Secretary may apply for, receive, and use grants–in–aid, funds, or services from the federal government or any of its units, or any public or private source made available to the Department for use in carrying out the powers and duties of the Secretary or the Department.
The Secretary shall review the State Disabilities Plan developed by the Board in accordance with § 7–132 of this subtitle.
The Secretary may approve the State Disabilities Plan or amend the Plan if the Secretary determines that the Plan developed by the Board is not in accordance with § 7–132 of this subtitle.
The Secretary shall request that the Board revise the State Disabilities Plan at least once every 4 years.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to implement the State Disabilities Plan as approved or as amended in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall submit an annual analysis of the State’s progress in implementing the State Disabilities Plan and related performance objectives to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on or before October 1 of each year.
The Secretary may create citizens’ advisory bodies that the Secretary considers necessary for the effective operation of the Department.

paragraph.text: The Department is the principal unit of State government responsible for developing, maintaining, revising, and enforcing statewide disability policies and standards throughout the units of State government.
In this capacity, the Department shall:

subparagraph.text: serve as the principal advisor to the Governor on the means and methods available to:

sub-subparagraph.text: implement and fund support to individuals with disabilities in accordance with the State Disabilities Plan;
modify or consolidate support to individuals with disabilities; and
collaborate with federal, regional, and local units of government to enhance the effectiveness of the provision and funding of support to individuals with disabilities;

subparagraph.text: annually recommend projects to the Department of Budget and Management for inclusion in the capital budget to promote access to State-owned facilities for individuals with disabilities;
assist units of State government to identify federal, State, local, and private funds available to the State for programs and services for individuals with disabilities; and
provide technical assistance to local jurisdictions in planning and implementing collaborative strategies consistent with the State Disabilities Plan.

subsection.text: The Department shall oversee and administer the following programs and units:

paragraph.text: constituent services and ombudsmen programs;
the Assistive Technology Guaranteed Loan Program under Subtitle 6 of this title; and
the Office of Personal Assistance Services, including the Attendant Care Program under Subtitle 4 of this title.

section.text: Unless the disclosure of information is otherwise prohibited by law, each unit of State government shall provide to the Secretary:

paragraph.text: at the request of the Secretary, information regarding current programs and services for individuals with disabilities; and
information regarding new or proposed programs and services for individuals with disabilities.

On or before July 1 of each year, each unit of State government shall develop a unit plan to implement the State Disabilities Plan as approved or amended by the Secretary under § 7-113(e) of this subtitle.
The unit plan shall contain an implementation schedule and measurable strategic performance objectives.
The Secretary may request amendments to a unit plan if the Secretary determines that the unit plan does not comply with the State Disabilities Plan.

subsection.text: On or before July 1 of each year, each unit of State government shall provide the Department with an evaluation of the unit’s performance in accordance with the unit’s plan developed under subsection (a) of this section.
The evaluation required under subsection (b) of this section shall:

paragraph.text: assess the unit’s performance against the strategic performance objectives established under subsection (a)(2) of this section; and
identify and measure:

subparagraph.text: consumer satisfaction;
gaps in services;
numbers of individuals waiting for services; and
progress made on achieving performance objectives.

subsection.text: The Secretary may provide technical assistance to any unit of State government to meet the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may waive the requirements of this section for any unit of State government.

section.text: There is a Maryland Commission on Disabilities.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of:

paragraph.text: the following members, appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: one individual with a physical disability;
one individual who has experienced mental illness;
two individuals with a developmental disability, including one with an intellectual disability;
one individual who is blind;
one individual who is deaf or hard of hearing;
one parent or foster parent of a child with a disability;
four members of the general public who have disabilities;
three representatives from statewide disability advocacy organizations;
one representative from the home health care industry;
one representative from a statewide organization of providers of services and support for individuals with disabilities;
one representative from the Alliance of Local Commissions on Disability; and

two representatives from the Board, one of whom shall be selected by the Secretary and one of whom shall be the Secretary of Budget and Management or the designee of the Secretary of Budget and Management;

paragraph.text: one representative from the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
one representative from the Maryland House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: In making the appointments required under subsection (a)(1) of this section, the Governor shall appoint members from among:

paragraph.text: the geographic regions of the State; and
diverse backgrounds.

subsection.text: A majority of the members shall be individuals with disabilities.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for the members of the Commission on October 1, 2007.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve more than two consecutive 3–year terms.

subsection.text: A member who fails to attend at least 50% of the regularly scheduled meetings of the Commission during any 12–month period shall be considered to have resigned.

section.text: From among the members of the Commission, the Governor shall designate a chair for a 2-year term.

subsection.text: A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
if the Secretary approves, is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide staff to the Commission as necessary.

section.text: Members of the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Department in carrying out its duties;
meet at least twice a year in meetings open to the public; and

serve on one or more subcommittees established by the Secretary to provide guidance to the Department on matters affecting individuals with disabilities, including public policy, outreach, and personal assistance services.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a subcommittee of the Commission created in accordance with § 7-123 of this subtitle shall be considered a public body under § 10-502(h) of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: There is an Interagency Disabilities Board convened by the Governor.
The purpose of the Board is to develop the State Disabilities Plan.

section.text: The Board consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Disabilities;
the Secretary of Aging, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Business and Economic Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Budget and Management, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Housing and Community Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Human Resources, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Planning, or the Secretary’s designee;
the State Superintendent of Schools, or the Superintendent’s designee;
the Secretary of Transportation, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office for Children, or the Executive Director’s designee;
the Director of the Governor’s Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, or the Director’s designee; and
representatives from any other unit of State government that the Governor designates.

subsection.text: The Secretary is the chair of the Board.
The chair shall direct the work of the Board.
The chair may establish subcommittees of the Board to carry out the duties established under this part.

section.text: The Department shall provide staff to the Board as necessary.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: provide ongoing examination of the structure and organization of the State’s system of services and support to individuals with disabilities to ensure equal access to support services and resources by individuals with disabilities;
facilitate the development of performance objectives that will result in a comprehensive, effective, efficient, and integrated service delivery system for individuals with disabilities;
develop an interagency funding approach to maximize efficiencies and streamline access to services and support for individuals with disabilities;
formulate policies on legislative issues and, under the direction of the Governor, communicate the policies to the General Assembly; and
develop the State Disabilities Plan.

subsection.text: The State Disabilities Plan shall provide for the coordination of support services that:

paragraph.text: ensure compliance with the federal Americans with Disabilities Act and other relevant federal and State provisions intended to protect the civil rights of individuals with disabilities;
are necessary for individuals with disabilities to achieve maximum participation in the mainstream of the community in the most integrated setting possible; and
address, on a statewide basis, the improvement of:

subparagraph.text: the capacity of communities to support individuals with disabilities with personal attendant care and other long-term care options that are self-directed;
the availability of accessible, integrated, and affordable housing options;
reliable transportation options;

employment and training options, including self-employment and noncongregant competitive opportunities available in an integrated environment in which there are individuals with and without disabilities;
somatic and mental health options;
accessible and universally designed technology;
support services for children, youth, and their families to enable them to achieve successful learning; and
family support services, including respite care.

subsection.text: The State Disabilities Plan shall assess the provision of and resources for support services for individuals with disabilities.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Human Resources.
“Respite care” means short-term care:

paragraph.text: of an individual with a developmental or functional disability described under § 7-202 of this subtitle; and
that is provided either within or outside the individual’s home to give temporary relief to the individual or the individual’s family.

subsection.text: An individual has a functional disability if the individual has a severe, chronic disability that:

paragraph.text: is attributable to a mental or physical impairment or a combination of mental and physical impairments, including a head injury;
is likely to continue indefinitely;
results in substantial functional limitations in at least three of the following areas of major life activity:

subparagraph.text: self-care;
receptive and expressive language;
learning;
mobility;
self-direction;
capacity for independent living; and
economic self-sufficiency; and

paragraph.text: reflects the individual’s need for a combination and sequence of special interdisciplinary or generic care, treatment, or other services that are:

subparagraph.text: lifelong or of extended duration; and
individually planned and coordinated.

subsection.text: An individual has a developmental disability if the individual has a functional disability that is manifested before the individual attains the age of 22 years.

paragraph.text: There is a Respite Care Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to provide respite care services in the State.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide respite care services through:

paragraph.text: local departments of social services; or
contracts with private nonprofit community-based providers.

section.text: Subject to the State budget, within a fiscal year an individual may receive:

paragraph.text: on an hourly basis, up to 24 hours of respite care provided in periods of less than 10 hours in any 24-hour period; and
on a daily basis, up to 14 days of respite care provided in periods of 10 or more hours in any 24-hour period.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations governing respite care services, including:

paragraph.text: mandatory standards; and
sliding fee schedules.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Council” means the Maryland Caregivers Support Coordinating Council.
“Department” means the Department of Human Resources.
There is a Maryland Caregivers Support Coordinating Council in the Department.
The purpose of the Council is to coordinate statewide planning, development, and implementation of family caregiver support services.

paragraph.text: The Council consists of the following members appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: two representatives from the Department of Human Resources;
three representatives from the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
one representative from the Department of Aging;
one representative from an area agency on aging;
one representative from the Department of Disabilities;
one representative from the Maryland Respite Care Coalition;
two consumers of respite care services;
three family caregivers; and
three representatives of organizations that provide or have interest or expertise in respite care services.

paragraph.text: In appointing members to the Council, to the extent possible, the Governor shall consider groups representing individuals with:

subparagraph.text: Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders;
developmental disabilities;
physical disabilities;
chronic illnesses;
mental or emotional conditions that require supervision; and
vulnerability to abuse or neglect.

subsection.text: The term of a member of the Council is 3 years.
The Governor shall appoint a chair of the Council from among the members.

paragraph.text: The Department shall provide staff for the Council.
An individual from the Department shall serve as executive director of the Council.

subsection.text: A member of the Council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Council; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: solicit and gather concerns of caregivers by:

subparagraph.text: conducting surveys;
holding public hearings;
establishing a telephone hotline for public access; and
other appropriate means;

paragraph.text: develop and distribute to interested parties a handbook of current respite care and other family caregiver services available in the State;
review successful respite care programs in other states;
develop a model family caregiver support program that incorporates best practices from existing programs in this and other states;
coordinate activities of existing and proposed family caregiver support services among State and local units;
research available funding sources and explore possibilities for additional funds; and
identify unmet needs and priorities for additional funds.

subsection.text: The Council shall report annually on its activities to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Attendant care services” means any of the following services for an eligible individual, which are certified as necessary by an attending physician or by a registered nurse:

paragraph.text: dressing;
preparing food and assisting with eating;
bathing and personal hygiene;
assisting with routine bodily functions, including bowel and urinary care;
moving into, out of, or turning in bed;
laundering and other clothing care; and
cleaning house and performing other services of daily care, including shopping and transportation, that the Department and the eligible individual request.

subsection.text: “Department” means the Department of Disabilities.
“Eligible individual” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: is at least 18 years old and under the age of 65 years at the time of the initial eligibility determination; and
has a severe chronic or permanent physical disability that precludes or significantly impairs the individual’s independent performance of essential activities of daily living, self–care, or mobility.

subsection.text: “Financial assistance” means a payment the Department makes to an eligible individual for attendant care services.
“Program” means the Attendant Care Program.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Disabilities.

paragraph.text: There is an Attendant Care Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to provide financial assistance to eligible individuals for attendant care services.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide financial assistance in accordance with a sliding payment scale that the Department establishes by regulation for each category of eligible individuals described in § 7–404(a) of this subtitle.
The Secretary shall designate an individual from the Department to serve as director of the Program.
The Secretary shall provide appropriate support services to the Program as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: The Department shall ensure that at any given time at least 50% of the eligible individuals receiving financial assistance under the Program are:

subparagraph.text: gainfully employed;
actively seeking employment; or
attending an institution of postsecondary or higher education, as defined in § 10–101 of the Education Article.

paragraph.text: The remainder of the eligible individuals receiving financial assistance under the Program shall be individuals who:

subparagraph.text: reside in a nursing facility or similar institution licensed to provide chronic or intermediate care and who will be deinstitutionalized as a result of the Program; or

are certified by an attending physician or certified nurse practitioner as being at risk of placement in a nursing facility or similar institution licensed to provide chronic or intermediate care if attendant care services are not received in the community.

paragraph.text: Subject to the availability of funds, the Secretary may waive the proportional requirement of subsection (a)(1) of this section in the event there is a waiting list of eligible individuals described in subsection(a)(2) of this section.
The Secretary may adopt regulations to establish priorities and procedures for a waiting list of eligible individuals.
An eligible individual receiving financial assistance may not be removed from the Program to achieve the proportional requirement under subsection (a)(1) of this section.

subsection.text: Financial assistance provided under the Program may not duplicate any other State or federal assistance for attendant care services that an eligible individual receives.
The Department shall limit participation in the Program to the number of eligible individuals who can be served with the funds appropriated for the Program in the State budget.
Each year, the Department shall review the eligibility of each individual receiving financial assistance.
The Program shall be funded as provided in the State budget.
The Department may:

paragraph.text: administer the Program directly; or
enter into a contract with a private organization to administer and operate the Program.

subsection.text: The Department shall administer this subtitle.
The Department shall adopt regulations for the operation of the Program.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Assistive technology” means any item, equipment, or device that is designed to enable an individual with a disability to become more independent or a more productive member of the community with an improved quality of life.

“Assistive technology” includes wheelchairs, motorized scooters, Braille equipment, voice simulation systems, scanners, assistive listening devices, telecommunications devices for the deaf, augmentative communication systems, environmental control systems, computers and adaptive peripherals, building modifications for accessibility, motor vehicles, and vehicle modifications.

subsection.text: “Board” means the Board of Directors of the Program.
“Department” means the Department of Disabilities.
“Fund” means the Assistive Technology Loan Fund.
“Program” means the Assistive Technology Loan Program.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Disabilities.

section.text: There is an Assistive Technology Loan Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to provide assistance for the purchase of assistive technology.
There is a Board of Directors of the Program.

subsection.text: The Board consists of:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Information Technology or the Secretary’s designee;
a representative from the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, Developmental Disabilities Administration, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene;
a representative of the State Department of Education Division of Rehabilitation Services, appointed by the State Superintendent of Schools; and
eight members of the public appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: Of the eight members of the public appointed by the Governor:

paragraph.text: four shall have significant experience in finance, accounting, investment management, or consumer lending; and
four shall have disabilities or assist individuals with disabilities, at least one of whom shall be a member of the Maryland Commission on Disabilities.
The term of a member appointed by the Governor is 4 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member appointed by the Governor may not serve more than two terms.

section.text: From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chair.

subsection.text: Six members of the Board are a quorum.
The Board shall meet at least quarterly or more often as necessary to carry out its duties efficiently.
A member:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a member may not financially benefit directly or indirectly from the activities of the Fund.
The Department shall provide staff to the Board.

section.text: Subject to §§ 7-609(a) and 7-610 of this subtitle, the Board may provide a guarantee of a loan or a subsidy of loan interest for a loan to an individual for the purchase of assistive technology.

subsection.text: To apply for a guarantee of a loan or a subsidy of loan interest, an applicant shall submit to the Board an application on the form that the Secretary provides.
The Board shall review the applications for guarantees of loans and subsidies of loan interest and approve or deny them based on information provided to or obtained by the Board.
The Board may enter into an agreement with an applicant to guarantee a loan or provide a subsidy for loan interest to the applicant only if the applicant demonstrates:

paragraph.text: that the loan to be guaranteed or the subsidy of loan interest will be used to acquire assistive technology;
the ability to repay the loan;
creditworthiness; and
the inability to qualify for a loan from a lending institution without a loan guarantee or a subsidy of loan interest.

subsection.text: The Board may elect to provide the borrower with an interest rate equivalent to the guaranteed rate by either guaranteeing the loan or subsidizing the interest rate if:

paragraph.text: a participating lending institution approves a loan without the requirement of a guarantee; and
the interest rate is higher than the interest rate otherwise available for a guaranteed loan.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this subtitle, the Board and lender jointly shall determine the amount and terms of the guarantee of the loan or the subsidy of loan interest.
The total aggregate amount of a loan guarantee may be up to 100% of the loan.

The total aggregate amount of the loan guarantees to be provided from the Fund in any given year shall be set annually by the Board in accordance with the requirements of the banks underwriting the loans at any given time.

section.text: If a borrower violates any provision of a loan guarantee or subsidy agreement or ceases to meet the requirements of this subtitle, on reasonable notice to the borrower, the Board may:

paragraph.text: withhold from the borrower further loan guarantees or subsidies until the borrower complies with the agreement or requirements; and
exercise any other remedy that the loan guarantee or subsidy agreement provides.

subsection.text: There is an Assistive Technology Loan Fund in the Department.
The purpose of the Fund is to provide guarantees of loans and subsidies of loan interest for the purchase of assistive technology.

paragraph.text: The Board shall administer the Fund.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.
If, at any time, the balance of the Fund exceeds the amount that the Board considers necessary to meet its obligations, on resolution of the Board, the excess shall revert to the General Fund.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: premiums and fees charged for the guarantees of loans or the subsidies of loan interest;
income from investment earnings;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, lease, or rental of collateral relating to the guarantees of loans or subsidies of loan interest;
money appropriated by the State to the Fund; and
any other money made available to the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be used to pay:

paragraph.text: guaranty payments required by loan defaults;
subsidies of loan interest;
expenses for administrative, legal, actuarial, technical assistance, and other services; and

any other expenses and disbursements that the Board authorizes for administering the Fund and financing the guarantees of loans and the subsidies of loan interest for the purchase of assistive technology.

section.text: Each year, the Treasurer shall report to the Board and the Secretary on:

paragraph.text: the status of the money invested under this subtitle;
the market value of the assets in the Fund as of the date of the report; and
the interest received from investments during the period that the report covers.

section.text: On or before January 1 of each year, the Board, through the Secretary, shall report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly, on the number, amount, and use of loans and subsidies for which the Program has provided guarantees of loans and subsidies of loan interest under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Blind” means:

paragraph.text: a visual acuity not exceeding 20/200 in the better eye with corrective lenses; or
a visual field of which the widest diameter subtends an angle of not more than 20 degrees.

subsection.text: “Deaf” means a permanent hearing loss:

paragraph.text: that necessitates the use of amplification devices to hear oral communication; or
for which amplification devices are ineffective.

subsection.text: “Disability” has the meaning stated in the federal Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, 42 U.S.C. § 12102.
“Housing accommodations” means real property, or a portion of real property, that is:

paragraph.text: offered for compensation; and
used or occupied, or intended to be used or occupied, as the residence or lodging of at least one individual.

subsection.text: “Mobility impaired” means an inability to carry objects or to move or travel without the use of an assistive device or service animal.
“Service animal” means a guide dog, signal dog, or other animal individually trained to do work or perform tasks for the benefit of an individual with a disability, including:

paragraph.text: guiding individuals with impaired vision;
alerting individuals with impaired hearing to an intruder or sounds;
providing minimal protection or rescue work;
pulling a wheelchair;
fetching dropped items; or
detecting the onset of a seizure.

subsection.text: “Service animal trainer” means a person who trains or raises service animals for individuals with disabilities, whether the person is a professional or volunteer.

It is the policy of the State to encourage and enable blind, visually impaired, deaf, and hard of hearing individuals to participate fully in the social and economic life of the State and to be employed.

It is the policy of the State that blind, visually impaired, deaf, and hard of hearing individuals shall be employed by the State, political subdivisions of the State, public schools, and other employers supported wholly or partly by public funds on the same terms and conditions as individuals without those disabilities, unless an individual’s disability prevents doing the work required.
Deaf and hard of hearing individuals in the State are recognized as a cultural minority with specialized communication needs.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “American Sign Language” means a visual-spatial method of communication that is a distinct language involving the hands, arms, facial markers, and body movements to communicate with others, including the conveyance of thoughts, words, emotions, and grammatical information.
American Sign Language is recognized as a language system designed to meet the specialized communication needs of deaf and hard of hearing individuals.

subsection.text: In this section, “Board” means the Board of Trustees of Blind Industries and Services of Maryland.
There is a Board of Trustees that is a body corporate under the name of “Blind Industries and Services of Maryland”.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 11 trustees appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the 11 trustees, at least 4 trustees shall be blind.
From among its members, the Board shall elect a chair and a treasurer.
The Board may elect another member to serve as chair if it is inconvenient or impossible for the regularly elected chair to serve.
The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2007.
The Governor shall fill a vacancy on the Board by appointment with the advice and consent of the Senate.
A member who is appointed after a term begins shall serve only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: A trustee is entitled to:

paragraph.text: per diem compensation for each Board or committee meeting attended in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses incurred in the performance of the trustee’s duties under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: maintain in Baltimore City a training and employment center for blind individuals;

operate the Blind Industries and Services of Maryland for the labor and manufactures of all blind adult residents of the State who give satisfactory evidence of character and ability to do the work required;
use the profits arising from the operation of the Blind Industries and Services of Maryland to further its mission;
acquire suitable quarters in the State;
keep proper records of its funds and accounts; and

report annually to the Governor, and subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly, and the chair of the Joint Audit Committee on the condition and operations of the Blind Industries and Services of Maryland, including a thorough discussion of its programs and the participation of the blind community in these programs.

subsection.text: The Board may:

paragraph.text: apply that portion of the endowment fund and annual income that the Board considers expedient to establish training and employment centers in any part of the State and to open a store for the sale of articles manufactured by blind individuals;

extend the benefits of the training and employment centers and the store to blind adults of the State who do not reside in institutions on any terms and under any regulations that the Board prescribes;
generally supervise and control the training and employment centers;
acquire and hold real, personal, and mixed property;
sue and be sued;
make, use, and alter a seal;
appoint a corporate secretary and other necessary employees and set their compensation; and

establish, maintain, direct, and supervise each matter concerning the Blind Industries and Services of Maryland, including the purchase of any machinery and materials that the Board considers suitable and necessary and the barter or exchange of articles or manufactures entrusted to the Board for disposal.

subsection.text: The Board shall be audited annually.

Individuals with disabilities, the parents of a minor child with a disability, and service animal trainers who are accompanied by an animal being trained or raised as a service animal have the same right as individuals without disabilities to the full and free use of the roads, sidewalks, public buildings, public facilities, and other public places.

paragraph.text: Individuals with disabilities, the parents of a minor child with a disability, and service animal trainers who are accompanied by an animal being trained or raised as a service animal are entitled to full and equal rights and privileges with respect to common carriers and other public conveyances or modes of transportation, places of public accommodations, and other places to which the general public is invited, subject only to any conditions and limitations of general application established by law.

The failure of a blind or visually impaired pedestrian to carry a cane predominantly white or metallic in color, with or without a red tip, or an individual with a disability or a parent of a minor child with a disability to use a service animal wearing an orange license tag or orange collar and on a leash, or to use a service animal in a place, accommodation, or conveyance listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection does not constitute contributory negligence per se.
This subsection does not apply to any accommodations or single family residence in which the occupants offer for compensation not more than one room.

An individual with a disability, a parent of a minor child with a disability, or a service animal trainer who is accompanied by an animal being trained or raised as a service animal is entitled to the same access as other members of the general public to housing accommodations in the State, subject to any conditions and limitations of general application established by law.

An individual with a disability, a parent of a minor child with a disability, or a service animal trainer who has, obtains, or may wish to obtain a service animal or an animal to be trained or raised as a service animal is entitled to full and equal access to housing accommodations.

An individual with a disability, a parent of a minor child with a disability, or a service animal trainer who is accompanied by a service animal or an animal being trained or raised as a service animal may not be required to pay extra compensation for the service animal, but the individual may be liable for damages to the premises or facilities that the service animal causes.

subsection.text: The following individuals have all the same rights and privileges conferred by law on other individuals:

paragraph.text: a blind or visually impaired pedestrian using a service animal and not carrying a cane predominantly white or metallic in color, with or without a red tip;
an individual with a disability and a parent of a minor child with a disability using a service animal not wearing an orange license tag or orange collar and on a leash;
an individual with a disability and a parent of a minor child with a disability using a service animal in a place, accommodation, or conveyance listed in § 7–704(b) of this subtitle; and
a service animal trainer who is accompanied by an animal that is being trained as a service animal.

subsection.text: This section does not require a physical modification of any place or vehicle in order to admit an individual with a disability or any other individual authorized under this subtitle to use a service animal who is accompanied by a service animal.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a service animal trainer may be accompanied by an animal that is being trained as a service animal in any place where an individual with a disability or a parent of a minor child with a disability has the right to be accompanied by a service animal.

An animal being trained as a service animal and accompanied by a service animal trainer may be excluded from a place described in paragraph (1) of this subsection if admitting the animal would create a clear danger of a disturbance or physical harm to an individual in the place.

An individual with a disability or a parent of a minor child with a disability who is accompanied by a service animal specially trained for that purpose in a place, accommodation, or conveyance listed in § 7–704(b) of this subtitle may not be required to pay extra compensation for the service animal, but the individual may be liable for any damages to the premises or facilities caused by the service animal.

A service animal trainer who is accompanied by an animal that is being trained as a service animal may not be required to pay extra compensation for the animal, but the service animal trainer organization that certifies the service animal may be liable for any personal injuries or damages to the premises or facilities caused by the service animal.

subparagraph.text: A person may not deny or interfere with the admittance of a service animal that accompanies an individual with a disability or a parent of a minor child with a disability in violation of this section.
A person who violates subparagraph (i) of this paragraph is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 for each offense.
A person may not deny or interfere with the admittance of an animal being trained as a service animal that accompanies a service animal trainer.
Subject to subsection (c)(2) of this section, a person who violates subparagraph (i) of this paragraph is subject to a fine not exceeding $25 for each offense.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not affect § 21-511 of the Transportation Article as to the right-of-way of a blind, deaf, or hard of hearing pedestrian crossing a highway.

This subtitle does not require a person who rents or leases housing accommodations to modify the person’s property or provide a higher degree of care for a blind or visually impaired individual than for an individual without those disabilities.

paragraph.text: A person may not deny or interfere with admittance to or enjoyment of a public place, accommodation, or conveyance described in § 7–704 of this subtitle or otherwise interfere with the rights of a blind, visually impaired, deaf, or hard of hearing individual under this subtitle.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 for each offense.

subsection.text: In addition to any other remedy provided under the Code for a violation of this subtitle, a person may maintain a civil action for injunctive relief against another person who denies or interferes with admittance to or enjoyment of a public place, accommodation, or conveyance described in § 7–704 of this subtitle or otherwise interferes with the rights of a blind, visually impaired, deaf, or hard of hearing individual under this subtitle.

section.text: Any organization or agency that requires a professional training program for the following individuals shall include a segment concerning the rights of individuals with disabilities who are accompanied by service animals:

paragraph.text: first responders;
emergency shelter operators; and
9–1–1 operators.

section.text: The Governor shall take suitable public notice of each October 15 as White Cane Safety Day by issuing a proclamation that:

paragraph.text: comments on the significance of the white cane;
calls on the public to observe the White Cane Law under §§ 7–704 through 7–707 of this subtitle and to take precautions necessary for the safety of blind and visually impaired individuals;
reminds the public of the policies with respect to blind and visually impaired individuals and urges cooperation with the policies;

emphasizes the need for awareness of the presence of blind and visually impaired individuals in the community and the need to keep roads, sidewalks, public accommodations, public buildings, public facilities, other public places, and other places to which the public is invited safe and functional for those individuals; and
offers assistance to blind and visually impaired individuals on appropriate occasions.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agencies of the Children’s Cabinet” includes:

paragraph.text: the Department of Budget and Management;
the Department of Disabilities;
the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Department of Human Resources;
the Department of Juvenile Services; and
the State Department of Education.
“Child in need of out–of–state placement” means a child who is recommended by a public agency for out–of–home placement outside of the State.
“Child in need of out–of–state placement” does not include a child:

subparagraph.text: placed in foster care, as defined in § 5–501 of the Family Law Article; or
who is in a hospital for 30 continuous days or less.

subsection.text: “Child with intensive needs” means a child who has behavioral, educational, developmental, or mental health needs that cannot be met through available public agency resources because:

paragraph.text: the child’s needs exceed the resources of a single public agency; or
there is no legally mandated funding source to meet the child’s needs.

subsection.text: “Core service agency” means the designated county or multicounty authority that is responsible for planning, managing, and monitoring publicly funded mental health services as provided under Title 10, Subtitle 12 of the Health – General Article.
“Council” means the State Coordinating Council for Children.
“Evidence–based” means meeting the criteria for an evidence–based early childhood home visiting service delivery model as defined by the federal Department of Health and Human Services.
“Executive Director” means the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office for Children.

paragraph.text: “Family” means an eligible child’s natural, adoptive, or foster parents.
“Family” includes:

subparagraph.text: a guardian;
a person acting as a parent of a child; and
a relative or stepparent with whom a child lives.

paragraph.text: “Home visiting program” means a program or initiative that:

subparagraph.text: contains home visiting as a primary service delivery strategy;
offers services on a voluntary basis to pregnant women, expectant fathers, and parents and caregivers of children from birth to kindergarten entry; and
targets participant outcomes that may include:

sub-subparagraph.text: improved maternal and child health;
prevention of child injuries, child abuse or maltreatment, and reduction of emergency department visits;
improvements in school readiness and achievement;
reduction in crime or domestic violence;
improvements in family economic self–sufficiency;
improvements in the coordination of and referrals to other community resources and supports; or
improvements in parenting skills related to child development.

paragraph.text: “Home visiting program” includes those program models identified in the Home Visiting Evidence of Effectiveness project of the federal Department of Health and Human Services.
“Home visiting program” does not include:

subparagraph.text: programs with few or infrequent visits;
programs in which home visiting is supplemental to other services; or

in–home services delivered through provisions of an individualized family service plan or an individualized education program under Part C or Part B of the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act.

subsection.text: “Hospital” has the meaning stated in § 19–301 of the Health – General Article.

“Local management board” means an entity established or designated by a county under Subtitle 3 of this title to ensure the implementation of a local, interagency service delivery system for children, youth, and families.
“Office” means the Governor’s Office for Children.
“Promising” means a home visiting program or practice that:

paragraph.text: does not yet meet the standard for evidence–based practices; and
meets the criteria of a promising approach as defined by the federal Department of Health and Human Services.

subsection.text: “Public agency” means a State or local government unit or a quasi–governmental entity.

paragraph.text: “Residential child care program” means an entity that provides 24–hour per day care for children within a structured set of services and activities that are designed to achieve specific objectives relative to the needs of the children served and that include the provision of food, clothing, shelter, education, social services, health, mental health, recreation, or any combination of these services and activities.
“Residential child care program” includes a program:

subparagraph.text: licensed by:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Department of Human Resources; or
the Department of Juvenile Services; and

subparagraph.text: that is subject to the licensing regulations of the members of the Children’s Cabinet governing the operations of residential child care programs.

subsection.text: It is the policy of the State to promote a stable, safe, and healthy environment for children and families that provides access to necessary services and supports in the least restrictive, most appropriate, and most effective environment possible, thereby increasing self–sufficiency and family preservation.
This policy shall be achieved through a comprehensive and coordinated interagency approach that:

paragraph.text: is family–driven, child–guided, home– and community–based, culturally and linguistically competent, individualized, and effective;
provides a continuum of care, opportunities, and supports that emphasize prevention, early intervention, and community–based services, as well as natural supports;
gives priority to children and families most at risk; and
engages and empowers families and children so that, to the extent possible, they will be well–represented in every facet of the child–family serving system and partners in their own care planning.

section.text: There is an Advisory Council to the Children’s Cabinet.
The purpose of the Advisory Council is to make recommendations to the Children’s Cabinet on:

paragraph.text: methods for meeting the policy and program goals of the State for integrated children and family programs;
coordinating State programs with programs operated by local governments, local management boards, and private groups;
building capacity to serve youths in their communities and at home;
reducing reliance on institutions as the primary mode of intervention for at-risk youth offenders;
promoting positive outcomes for youths;
funding practices that prevent juvenile crimes and delinquency; and
reducing disproportionate minority confinement.

subsection.text: Each county shall establish and maintain a local management board to ensure the implementation of a local interagency service delivery system for children, youth, and families.
A county may designate as the local management board:

paragraph.text: a quasi-public nonprofit corporation that is not an instrumentality of the county government; or
a public agency that is an instrumentality of the county government.

section.text: A local management board may be composed of:

paragraph.text: public and private community representatives who share the responsibility for implementing a community–based, interagency, family–focused service delivery system for children, youth, and families;
a senior representative or department head of the:

subparagraph.text: local health department;
local office of the Department of Juvenile Services;
core service agency;
local school system; and
local department of social services;

paragraph.text: family members or family advocates; and
youth or youth advocates.

section.text: A local management board shall:

paragraph.text: strengthen the decision-making capacity at the local level;
design and implement strategies that achieve clearly defined results for children, youth, and families as articulated in a local 5-year strategic plan for children, youth, and families;
maintain standards of accountability for locally agreed upon results for children, youth, and families;
influence the allocation of resources across systems as necessary to accomplish the desired results;
build local partnerships to coordinate children, youth, and family services within the county to eliminate fragmentation and duplication of services; and
create an effective system of services, supports, and opportunities that improve outcomes for all children, youth, and families.

section.text: The members of the Children’s Cabinet shall adopt regulations that:

paragraph.text: specify the roles and responsibilities of local management boards;
establish minimum standards for the composition of local management boards;
establish fiscal and program accountability in the implementation of community partnership agreements and the use of other State resources by local management boards;
establish procedures to ensure the confidentiality of information shared by local management board members and employees in accordance with State and federal law; and
generally relate to the operation of local management boards.

section.text: On or before October 1 of each year, the Maryland Association of Local Management Board Directors shall, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, submit to the Senate Finance Committee, the House Committee on Ways and Means, and the Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families, a report summarizing, with respect to the programs implemented under § 8-505(d) of this title:

paragraph.text: each local management board’s activities;
the amount of money spent on the programs; and
the effectiveness of the programs.

section.text: There is a State Coordinating Council for Children in the Office.

subsection.text: The Council consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office for Children, or the Executive Director’s designee;
the Secretary of Juvenile Services, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Human Resources, or the Secretary’s designee; and
the State Superintendent of Schools, or the Superintendent’s designee.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Budget and Management, or the Secretary’s designee, shall serve as a nonvoting ex officio Council member.
The Secretary of Disabilities, or the Secretary’s designee, shall serve as a nonvoting ex officio Council member.
The Children’s Cabinet shall designate up to three individuals to serve on the Council on a rotating basis to represent each of the following stakeholder groups:

paragraph.text: family members or family advocates; and
youth or youth advocates.
The office of chair of the Council shall rotate annually among the members of the Council appointed under § 8–402(a) of this subtitle, in the order listed in that subsection.
The term of the chair is 1 year.

subsection.text: The Office shall provide staff support for the Council.

section.text: The Council shall address the population of children who are in out–of–state placements or are recommended for out–of–state placements, including:

paragraph.text: reviewing recommendations for State funding of the individual placement of a child in need of out–of–state placement;
coordinating the monitoring of out–of–state residential facilities for children as required by statute;
tracking the types, costs, and effectiveness of services required to meet the needs of children who are recommended for out–of–state placements;
providing training and technical assistance to local agency and community partners;
making recommendations to the appropriate secretary on the development of regulations to carry out this subtitle; and
performing other related activities that the Children’s Cabinet identifies.

section.text: There is a local care team in each county.

subsection.text: Each local care team shall include:

paragraph.text: at least one representative from:

subparagraph.text: the Department of Juvenile Services;
the Developmental Disabilities Administration;
the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Administration;
the Mental Hygiene Administration or the local core service agency;
the local school system;
the local health department;
the local department of social services; and
the local management board;

paragraph.text: a parent, parent advocate, or both, appointed by the chair of the local care team in consultation with the child advocacy community; and
a nonvoting representative of the local office of the division of rehabilitative services to represent individuals who are 16 years old and older.

subsection.text: Each local care team shall establish the terms of its members.
Each local care team shall select its chair from among its members for a designated term of office.
Each local care team:

paragraph.text: shall determine which of its members will have responsibility for its administrative functions; and
if two or more members will share the responsibility, shall determine the rotation of the administrative functions.

subsection.text: Subject to the availability of funds, a parent or parent advocate who is a member of a local care team may receive:

paragraph.text: the compensation provided in the State or local budget; and
reimbursement for expenses, in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations.

section.text: A local care team shall:

paragraph.text: be a forum for:

subparagraph.text: families of children with intensive needs to receive assistance with the identification of individual needs and potential resources to meet identified needs; and
interagency discussions and problem solving for individual child and family needs and systemic needs;

paragraph.text: refer children and families to:

subparagraph.text: care management entities when appropriate; and
available local and community resources;

paragraph.text: provide training and technical assistance to local agency and community partners;

identify and share resource development needs and communicate with the care management entity, local core service agencies, provider networks, local management boards, and other local care teams in surrounding jurisdictions; and
discuss a request for a voluntary placement agreement for a child with a developmental disability or a mental illness under § 5–525 of the Family Law Article.

subsection.text: A parent or guardian of a child and the child’s attorney may attend any meeting of the Council or the local care team at which the child’s care is discussed.

At least 10 days before the meeting, the Council or local care team shall notify each parent or guardian of the child and the child’s attorney of the date, time, and location of any meeting the Council or the local care team plans to hold to discuss the child’s out–of–state placement.
The Council or the local care team shall notify each parent or guardian of the child and the child’s attorney in writing of:

paragraph.text: any decision the Council or local care team makes concerning the child’s out–of–state placement; and
the right of the parent, guardian, or attorney to appeal a decision made by the Council or the local care team concerning the child’s out–of–state placement.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Fund” means the Children’s Cabinet Fund.
There is a Children’s Cabinet Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund:

paragraph.text: consists of money appropriated, transferred, credited, or paid into the Fund from any source; and
includes money for out-of-home care and services to prevent out-of-home placements.

subsection.text: At the end of each fiscal year any unspent money in the Fund shall revert to the General Fund.

section.text: Expenditures from the Fund shall be made:

paragraph.text: in accordance with the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
to reflect the priorities, policies, and procedures that the Children’s Cabinet adopts.

subsection.text: A local management board shall apply for money from the Fund in accordance with procedures established by the Children’s Cabinet.
In connection with an application for money under subsection (a) of this section, a local management board shall develop and submit a community partnership agreement that:

paragraph.text: reflects coordination with:

subparagraph.text: the State’s 3-year plan for children, youth, and families; and

any local government plan for services for children, youth, and families, including the local substance abuse plan developed in accordance with Title 8, Subtitle 10 of the Health - General Article; and

paragraph.text: addresses the priorities and strategies of the county for meeting the identified needs of children and families as articulated in the local management board’s 5-year strategic plan regarding:

subparagraph.text: youth development;
prevention services;
crisis and early intervention;
services for children at risk of out-of-home placement or returning from out-of-home placement; and
out-of-home placement and treatment.

subsection.text: The Children’s Cabinet may disburse money to a local management board subject to the terms, conditions, performance measures, or outcome evaluations that the Children’s Cabinet considers necessary.
The local management board shall use the money to implement:

paragraph.text: a local interagency services delivery system for children, youth, and families in accordance with the community partnership agreement; and
any terms, conditions, and performance measures that the Children’s Cabinet requires.

subsection.text: The State shall fund only evidence–based and promising home visiting programs for improving parent and child outcomes, as provided in the State budget.
Not less than 75% of the State funding for home visiting programs shall be made available to evidence–based home visiting programs.

paragraph.text: The Governor’s Office for Children and the agencies of the Children’s Cabinet, with input from local management boards, local home visiting programs, and the Early Childhood Advisory Council, shall require the recipients of State funding for home visiting programs to submit reports to the Governor’s Office for Children on a regular basis.
Home visiting program reports shall include, at a minimum:

subparagraph.text: a verifiable accounting of the State funds spent;
the number and demographic characteristics of the individuals served; and
the outcomes achieved by the home visiting programs.

subsection.text: The Governor’s Office for Children and the agencies of the Children’s Cabinet shall develop a standardized reporting mechanism for the purpose of collecting information about and monitoring the effectiveness of State–funded home visiting programs.

On or before December 1, 2013, and at least every 2 years thereafter, the Governor’s Office for Children and the agencies of the Children’s Cabinet shall submit a report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the Senate Finance Committee, the House Ways and Means Committee, and the Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families on the implementation and outcomes of State–funded home visiting programs.

section.text: The State Department of Education is the fiscal agent for the Fund.

In this subtitle, “at-risk youth prevention and diversion program” means services provided to school-aged youth and their families to prevent or divert youth from entering the juvenile justice system and to help make them ready for adulthood by age 21.
An at-risk youth prevention and diversion program may be:

subparagraph.text: community-based;
school-based;
neighborhood-based; or
faith-based; and

paragraph.text: nonresidential.

subsection.text: At-risk youth prevention and diversion programs shall be coordinated, monitored, and supported by local management boards.
A local management board shall:

paragraph.text: develop a request for funds based on the recommendations of the local planning group convened in accordance with § 8-605(b) of this subtitle;
award funds to local agencies or organizations to provide direct services;
monitor and evaluate at-risk youth prevention and diversion program performance;
provide technical assistance to at-risk youth prevention and diversion programs as needed;
promote cost-effectiveness strategies;
measure at-risk youth prevention and diversion program outcomes; and
provide fiscal and program reports to the Office.

subsection.text: As part of the prevention element of the 3-year plan developed by the Children’s Cabinet establishing priorities and strategies for the coordinated delivery of services for children and families, the local management board shall:

paragraph.text: assess the adequacy, availability, and accessibility of current community-based services that:

subparagraph.text: prevent and divert entry and reentry into the juvenile system;
provide alternatives to incarceration and institutionalization;
prevent and divert criminal behavior; and
increase personal responsibility and self-sufficiency;

paragraph.text: identify unserved neighborhoods or communities with critical needs and significant numbers of at-risk or delinquent youth; and
recommend programs that can be established or enhanced to address the unmet needs of youth and their families.

subsection.text: A local management board shall apply to the Office for funding for an at-risk youth prevention and diversion program.

The application shall demonstrate that the local management board has convened a local planning group consisting of parents, youth, and representatives of public and private agencies that have knowledge of and experience working with at-risk youth and families.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agency” means:

paragraph.text: the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Department of Human Resources; or
the Department of Juvenile Services.

subsection.text: “Certified program administrator” means an individual who is:

paragraph.text: certified by the State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals under Title 20 of the Health Occupations Article; and

responsible for the day–to–day management and operation of a residential child care program and for assuring the care, treatment, safety, and protection of the children in the residential child care program.

subsection.text: “Plan” means the State Resource Plan for Residential Child Care Programs.
“Provider” means a for profit or not for profit entity licensed by an agency to operate a residential child care program.
Except as provided in § 8–707 of this subtitle, “residential child care program” does not include sites licensed by the Developmental Disabilities Administration.

section.text: It is the intent of the General Assembly to:

paragraph.text: improve the quality of care provided by residential child care programs;
provide the same quality of care to all children placed in residential child care programs; and
develop a system that expands services provided by residential child care programs to counties that are underserved.

subsection.text: There is a State Resource Plan for Residential Child Care Programs.
The purpose of the Plan is to enhance access to services provided by residential child care programs.

On or before July 1 of each year, the Office shall develop the Plan in consultation with the agencies, providers, counties, child advocates, consumers, and any other State unit, entity, or person that the Office identifies as having relevant information or that is interested in the development of the Plan.
The Plan shall:

paragraph.text: provide a framework for the Office and the agencies to procure residential child care program services that meet the needs identified in the Plan;
provide the following information on residential child care programs:

subparagraph.text: the county where each program is operated;
the provider for each program;
the actual capacity and utilization rate for each program;
the ages of the children in each program;
the county where each child in a program lived at the time the child entered out-of-home placement;
the services children require and a description of how those services are being provided;
the agency that placed children in each program; and
any other information the Office or the agencies, providers, or counties consider relevant;

paragraph.text: identify the types of services needed in residential child care programs and the estimated number of children requiring those services in each county;
identify the counties where the services identified in item (3) of this subsection are insufficiently supplied;
establish an incentive fund for residential child care program development in the counties identified in item (4) of this subsection; and

identify the reasons children are placed in residential child care programs outside of the counties where the children lived at the time they entered out-of-home placement in accordance with § 5-525 of the Family Law Article.

subsection.text: On or before January 1 of each year, the Office shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the Senate Finance Committee and the House Health and Government Operations Committee on the Plan’s findings and recommendations.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Licensing agency” means:

subparagraph.text: the Department of Human Resources; and
the Department of Juvenile Services.

paragraph.text: “Statement of need” means an official certification of public need for the location and establishment of a residential child care program in a county issued by a licensing agency under this section.
