The Board of Public Works may waive the State’s right of recovery if the Board determines that there is good cause for releasing the transferor, transferee, or owner from this obligation.

section.text: Subject to approval by the Board of Public Works, the Secretary may adopt regulations to carry out this part.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means the Senior Citizen Activities Center Operating Fund.

“Senior citizen activities center” means a community or neighborhood facility in which a broad spectrum of services are organized and provided to seniors and their spouses, including health, social, nutritional, educational, and recreational services.
There is a Senior Citizen Activities Center Operating Fund.
The Fund shall be used to supplement, but may not be used to supplant, any existing funding for senior citizen activities centers in the State budget.
The Secretary shall administer the Fund.
The Secretary may adopt regulations to carry out this part.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: The Fund consists of appropriations that are made to the Fund from the State budget.
For each fiscal year, the Governor shall include in the annual State budget an appropriation of $500,000 for the Fund.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, money from the Fund shall be distributed to counties for senior citizen activities centers based on a competitive grant process administered by the Department.
At least 50% of the Fund shall be distributed for senior citizen activities centers on the basis of need, as determined by the Department, to counties:

subparagraph.text: that have developed and submitted a local strategic plan for economic development that has been approved by the Secretary of Business and Economic Development; and
for which:

sub-subparagraph.text: the average rate of unemployment for the most recent 18-month period for which data is available is greater than 150% of the average rate of unemployment for the entire State during that same period; or

the average per capita personal income for the most recent 24-month period for which data is available is equal to or less than 67% of the average personal per capita income for the entire State during that same period.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be invested and reinvested in the same manner as other State funds.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Council” means the Innovations in Aging Services Advisory Council.
“Program” means the Innovations in Aging Services Program.
There is an Innovations in Aging Services Program in the Department.
The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: provide competitive funding grants to design and test innovative ideas in programs and services for seniors;
publicly disseminate the results of the tests; and
help meet the need for personnel trained to provide services to seniors in the State.
With the advice of the Council, the Secretary shall:

subparagraph.text: develop annually a Program plan; and
submit the plan to the Governor and General Assembly for approval as part of the annual State budget.

paragraph.text: The plan shall set forth priorities for:

subparagraph.text: funding grants for innovative services to seniors; and
training personnel who provide services to seniors in the State.

paragraph.text: The plan shall include provisions for:

subparagraph.text: funding grants that are sought by Communities for a Lifetime to the extent practicable; and
evaluating any program funded under the plan.

subsection.text: The Secretary may accept money from any public or private source to fund grants awarded under this subtitle.
There is an Innovations in Aging Services Advisory Council in the Department.
The Council consists of the following 15 members:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Aging;
the chair of the Maryland Commission on Aging or the chair’s designee;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene or the Secretary’s designee;
one member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate;
one member of the Maryland House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker; and
the following 10 members appointed by the Secretary of Aging:

subparagraph.text: five representatives of organizations providing services to seniors;
two representatives of senior consumers of services to seniors;
a director of an area agency;
a representative of a Community for a Lifetime; and
a representative of the University of Maryland Center on Aging.

subsection.text: The Secretary is the chair of the Council.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the Council is 4 years.
The terms of the members appointed by the Secretary are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Council on October 1, 2007.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall solicit grant proposals to implement the Program priorities approved by the Governor and the General Assembly under § 10-603(a) of this subtitle.
With the advice of the Council, the Secretary shall award grants funded in accordance with the approved Program priorities.
The Secretary shall provide for the evaluation, by recognized authorities in the field of services to seniors, of the programs funded by the grants.

section.text: The Secretary shall report annually to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the evaluations of programs funded under this subtitle.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Adult dependent” means an individual who is:

paragraph.text: at least 18 years old;
an individual with long-term care needs; and
the spouse, parent, stepparent, grandparent, child, stepchild, sibling, aunt, uncle, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, mother-in-law, or father-in-law of a family caregiver.

subsection.text: “Family caregiver” means an individual who cares for an adult dependent.
“Individual with long-term care needs” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: is unable to perform at least three activities of daily living without substantial assistance from another individual; or

subparagraph.text: is unable to perform at least one activity of daily living without substantial assistance from another individual; and
requires substantial supervision to protect the individual from threats to the individual’s health and safety due to severe cognitive impairment.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Family Caregiver Assistance Program.
There is a Family Caregiver Assistance Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to provide grants to eligible family caregivers to supplement the unmet expenses of caring for an adult dependent.
Funding for the Program shall be as provided in the State budget.
The Secretary may accept money provided by other public and private sources, including federal funds, to provide grants under the Program.
A family caregiver is eligible for a grant from the Program if:

paragraph.text: the family caregiver resides with an adult dependent;
the adult dependent has been certified by a licensed physician in the State as an individual with long-term care needs for at least 180 consecutive days during the year; and
the family caregiver’s household income is 200% or less of the State median income, as adjusted for family size, in accordance with regulations adopted by the Secretary.

subsection.text: The Program may provide eligible family caregivers with a grant of up to $500 per household per year.
A grant may be used to fund goods and services required to provide care for an adult dependent including:

paragraph.text: durable medical equipment;
medical bills;
medical supplies;
prescription or over-the-counter medications;
repairs or modifications to the home; and
respite care for the family caregiver.

section.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to implement the Program;

work in cooperation with the Department of Disabilities, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, and the Maryland Caregivers Support Coordinating Council to promote the Program to family caregivers throughout the State; and
report annually to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on:

subparagraph.text: the number of grant requests received;
the value of grants provided to family caregivers;
the purposes for which the grants were provided; and
the number of grant requests that the Program was unable to fund and the reason why those requests were not funded.

section.text: The regulations required to be adopted under § 10-705 of this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: ensure that the total amount of funding available for grants under the Program is allocated among all counties based on each county’s proportion of the total State adult population; and
provide that if a county is unable to use its allocation, any unspent funds shall revert to the Program and be redistributed among all counties.

section.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to:

paragraph.text: establish a comprehensive, strategic State plan to address the aging–in–place preference of current and future seniors;
provide available resources to local communities to enhance aging–in–place services and facilitate the independence of older adults; and
promote a State aging–in–place program that overcomes barriers in housing, transportation, health care, employment, and social and civic engagement.

section.text: There is a Maryland Communities for a Lifetime Program in the Department.
The Department shall collect and make available best practices on policies to encourage aging–in–place.

subsection.text: A county or municipal corporation may establish a process to certify communities as Communities for a Lifetime under the Maryland Communities for a Lifetime Program.
The Department shall recommend criteria that local jurisdictions may use to certify Communities for a Lifetime, including:

paragraph.text: the extent to which a community has sought and plans to expand public health, prevention, and wellness programs that serve older adults;
the extent to which a community has sought and plans to expand affordable transportation options;
the extent to which a community has sought and plans to expand affordable rental housing and the ability to own affordable homes;
the extent to which a community has sought and plans to expand employment, civic engagement, recreation, and leisure options for older adults; and
the extent to which a community has sought and plans to expand other initiatives that boost the abilities of older adults to age in place.

subsection.text: A Community for a Lifetime shall submit to the Department on or before September 1 each year a progress report on the community’s efforts to enable aging in place and a report on the community’s plans to enable aging in place in the future.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Local long–term care ombudsman entity” means an entity designated by the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman to assist in carrying out the duties of the Program.
“Long–term care facility” means:

paragraph.text: a nursing facility, as defined in § 19–301 of the Health – General Article; or
an assisted living program, as defined in § 19–1801 of the Health – General Article.

subsection.text: “Office” means the Office of the Long–Term Care Ombudsman established under this subtitle.
“Ombudsman” means:

paragraph.text: the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman; and
any individual, whether a paid employee or a volunteer, who is designated by the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman as an ombudsman.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Long–Term Care Ombudsman Program established under this subtitle.
“Resident” means a resident of a long–term care facility located in the State.
“State Long–Term Care Ombudsman” means the individual selected by the Secretary under § 10–903 of this subtitle.
There is a Long–Term Care Ombudsman Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to fulfill the requirements of:

paragraph.text: the Program under this subtitle; and
the federal Older Americans Act, including the requirements of 42 U.S.C. § 3058G.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations necessary to carry out this subtitle.
The regulations adopted under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall establish:

subparagraph.text: the requirements for an annual review by the Department of all ombudsman activities; and
the process for assisting individuals with organizing and operating a resident council and a family council in a long–term care facility.

subsection.text: There is an Office of the Long–Term Care Ombudsman in the Department.

paragraph.text: Unless the Secretary is subject to a conflict of interest that cannot be removed, the Secretary shall select a State Long–Term Care Ombudsman.

If the Secretary is subject to a conflict of interest that cannot be removed, the Secretary shall designate another individual, who is not subject to a conflict of interest, to select the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman.

subsection.text: The State Long–Term Care Ombudsman:

paragraph.text: shall personally administer the Office;
shall have expertise and experience in the field of long–term care advocacy;
may not have any conflict of interest with the position; and
shall, on a full–time basis, perform duties related to the Program.

subsection.text: The State Long–Term Care Ombudsman shall personally or through designated ombudsmen:

paragraph.text: identify, investigate, and resolve complaints from any source made by, or on behalf of, a resident relating to any action, inaction, or decision, that may adversely affect the health, safety, welfare, or rights of a resident including the welfare and rights of residents with respect to the appointment and activities of guardians and representative payees, of:

subparagraph.text: a provider, or a representative of a provider, of long–term care services;
a public agency; or
a health or social service agency;

paragraph.text: represent the interests of residents before governmental agencies and seek administrative, legal, and other remedies to protect the health, safety, welfare, and rights of residents;
provide information as appropriate to other agencies and the public regarding the problems and concerns of residents;

inform residents, family members, and others acting on behalf of residents about how to access the assistance and services of the Office and the services and assistance of other providers or agencies, including legal services;
ensure regular and timely access to and response from the Office;

comment on, facilitate public comment on, and recommend changes to existing or proposed laws, rules, regulations, and other governmental policies and actions that affect the health, safety, welfare, and rights of residents;
provide technical support for the development of resident and family councils to protect the well–being and rights of residents;
provide for the education and training of ombudsmen;
educate facilities, agencies, and staff members concerning the rights and welfare of residents;
promote the development of citizen organizations to advocate for the well–being and rights of residents;
provide services to assist residents in protecting the health, safety, welfare, and rights of residents; and
carry out any other activities that the Secretary determines to be appropriate or that are required by the federal Older Americans Act.

subsection.text: Entities eligible to be designated as local long–term care ombudsman entities shall:

paragraph.text: have demonstrated capability to carry out the responsibilities of the Office;
be public or nonprofit entities;
be free of conflicts of interest; and
meet any additional requirements that the Secretary and the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman specify.
The Secretary, in consultation with area agencies on aging, shall adopt regulations to establish requirements for training and designating ombudsmen, including in–service training.

The regulations shall prohibit the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman from designating an individual as an ombudsman unless the individual has successfully completed the required training and satisfied the requirements for designation.

section.text: In accordance with requirements of the federal Older Americans Act, an ombudsman shall have access to:

paragraph.text: long–term care facilities and residents;
the medical and social records of a resident, if:

subparagraph.text: the ombudsman has the permission of the resident or the legal representative of the resident; or
the resident is unable to consent and has no legal representative;

paragraph.text: the records that are necessary to investigate a complaint if:

subparagraph.text: a legal guardian of the resident refuses to give permission to access the records;
the ombudsman has reasonable cause to believe that the guardian is not acting in the best interests of the resident; and
the ombudsman obtains the approval of the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman;

paragraph.text: the administrative records, policies, and documents of long–term care facilities to which the residents or members of the general public have access; and
copies of all licensing and certification records maintained by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene or any other State unit with respect to long–term care facilities.

subsection.text: The Secretary, in consultation with area agencies on aging, shall adopt regulations to govern conflicts of interest to ensure that:

paragraph.text: no individual, or member of the immediate family of an individual, involved in the designation of the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman or a local long–term care ombudsman entity, is subject to a conflict of interest; and
no ombudsman or immediate family member of an ombudsman is subject to a conflict of interest.

subsection.text: The Secretary, in consultation with area agencies on aging, shall adopt regulations governing the confidentiality of information and documents, including resident records, facility records, and complainant identification.

section.text: The Secretary shall require the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman to coordinate ombudsman services with:

paragraph.text: the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Department of Human Resources;
protection and advocacy systems for individuals with developmental disabilities and mental illnesses; and
legal assistance.

section.text: The Secretary shall establish and maintain a statewide uniform reporting system for the Program to collect and analyze data relating to complaints and conditions in long–term facilities and to residents for the purpose of identifying and resolving significant problems.

The State Long–Term Care Ombudsman shall submit an annual report to the Governor and the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, on the activities of the Program that includes recommendations of the State Long–Term Care Ombudsman for improving services for residents.

subsection.text: In accordance with 42 U.S.C. § 3058G(j)(1), a person may not willfully interfere with an ombudsman’s performance of an official duty.
A person may not retaliate or make reprisals with respect to any person who filed a complaint with, or provided information to, an ombudsman.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,500.

section.text: An ombudsman is not liable under State law for good faith performance of official duties.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of Directors of the Maryland Legal Services Corporation.
“Corporation” means the Maryland Legal Services Corporation.
“Eligible client” means a person who is unable to afford legal assistance as determined under § 11-603 of this title.
“Fund” means the Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund.

paragraph.text: “Grantee” means a nonprofit organization that:

subparagraph.text: is qualified under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code;
provides legal assistance to eligible clients; and
receives financial assistance under § 11-501 of this title from the Corporation.

paragraph.text: “Grantee” includes:

subparagraph.text: the Legal Aid Bureau, Inc.;
the Maryland Disability Law Center; and
the Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service, Inc.

subsection.text: “Internal Revenue Code” means:

paragraph.text: Title 26 of the United States Code; and
regulations adopted under Title 26 of the United States Code.
“Legal assistance” means the legal representation of eligible clients by grantees.
“Legal assistance” includes:

subparagraph.text: training;
research;
coordination with private attorneys; and
other activities necessary to ensure the delivery of quality legal services.

section.text: The General Assembly finds and declares that:

paragraph.text: there is a need to provide equal access to the system of justice for individuals seeking redress of grievances;
reduction of federal funds has diminished the availability of legal services provided by existing statewide legal services programs;
there is a need to continue and expand legal assistance to those who would otherwise be unable to afford adequate legal counsel;
the availability of legal services reaffirms faith in our government of laws;
the funding of legal assistance programs for those who are unable to afford legal counsel will serve the ends of justice and the general welfare of the public; and

attorneys providing legal assistance must have full freedom to protect the best interests of their clients in keeping with the Maryland Rules of Professional Conduct and the high standards of the legal profession.
There is a Maryland Legal Services Corporation.
The Corporation is a nonstock corporation.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Corporation is to receive and distribute funds to grantees that provide legal assistance to eligible clients in civil proceedings or matters.

paragraph.text: The Corporation shall maintain:

subparagraph.text: its principal office in the State; and
a designated agent to accept service of process.

paragraph.text: The Corporation shall file the name and address of the designated agent with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

subsection.text: The Corporation is exempt from any special tax, property tax, recordation tax, or transfer tax imposed by the State or a political subdivision of the State.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, the Corporation is not a unit or instrumentality of the State.
The Board shall appoint an executive director of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: The executive director is the chief executive officer of the Corporation.
Subject to this title and policies established by the Board, the executive director has the authority and responsibility for:

subparagraph.text: administering the affairs of the Corporation;
appointing and removing employees as necessary to carry out the purposes of this title;
making grants;
entering into contracts;
exercising powers incident to the office of the executive director; and
performing other duties that the Board prescribes.

subsection.text: The executive director is entitled to a salary as provided in the budget of the Corporation.
The executive director may be removed by a majority of the Board.

A political test or political qualification may not be used in selecting, appointing, promoting, or taking any other personnel action with respect to an officer, agent, or employee of the Corporation.
Employees of the Corporation are entitled to salaries as provided in the budget of the Corporation.
Employees of the Corporation are not employees of the State.

section.text: To the extent consistent with this title, the Corporation shall exercise the powers granted to a nonstock corporation under Title 5, Subtitle 2 of the Corporations and Associations Article.
The Corporation shall indemnify the members of the Board and the officers, agents, and employees of the Corporation to the extent authorized under the Maryland General Corporation Law.

paragraph.text: The Corporation shall publish an annual report.
The Corporation shall submit the annual report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

subsection.text: The report shall include a description of services provided.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 486 OF 2010 //

subsection.text: The executive director shall prepare an annual budget for the Corporation.

paragraph.text: For informational purposes only, the Corporation shall submit its budget to the General Assembly in conjunction with the budget request of the Judicial Branch of the State government on November 1 of each year.

The informational budget required under this subsection shall include 3 years of data, including the most recently completed fiscal year, an estimate for the current fiscal year, and an estimate for the next fiscal year, including:

subparagraph.text: a summary of total expenditures and the sources of revenue that support that spending;
line item expenditure detail for personnel, operating expenses, and grants, including individual grantees;
narrative explanation of all revenue and spending changes between the current fiscal year and the next fiscal year;
performance measurement data that details the use of funds; and
detail on the Corporation’s reserve fund, including actual and estimated end of fiscal year balances, transfers to and from the reserve fund, and the policies governing the reserve fund.

subsection.text: There is a Board of Directors of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of:

subparagraph.text: nine voting members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate; and
the executive director, who is a nonvoting ex officio member.

paragraph.text: Voting members shall be residents of the State and shall represent the different geographical regions of the State.
Five voting members shall be lawyers admitted to the Bar in the State and four voting members shall be nonlawyers.

subsection.text: A voting member of the Board is not an officer or employee of the State.

paragraph.text: The term of office of a voting member is 3 years.
At the end of a term a voting member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The terms of voting members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2007.
If a vacancy occurs during the term of a voting member, the Governor shall fill the vacancy.
A voting member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A voting member may not be reappointed for more than 2 consecutive terms immediately following the member’s initial term.
A voting member may be removed by a vote of seven members.
A voting member may only be removed for:

subparagraph.text: malfeasance in office;
persistent neglect of or inability to discharge duties; or
offenses involving moral turpitude.

subsection.text: From among its voting members, the Board annually shall elect a chair.
From among its members, the Board shall appoint a secretary, a treasurer, and other officers.

section.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for necessary expenses incurred in connection with service on the Board as provided in the budget of the Corporation.

subsection.text: The Board shall meet at least 4 times a year.
Except as provided in § 10-508 of the State Government Article, a meeting of the Board shall be open to the public.

In the State operating budget or in any supplemental budget that the Governor submits to the General Assembly, the Governor shall appropriate at least $500,000 each year to the Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund established under § 11-402 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: To support or add to the appropriation under subsection (a) of this section, on July 1 of each year, the Governor may transfer to the Fund up to $500,000 from the portion of abandoned property funds deposited in the General Fund of the State under § 17-317 of the Commercial Law Article.

If, after deducting all costs of administering the abandoned property fund, the balance in the portion of abandoned property funds deposited in the General Fund of the State under § 17-317 of the Commercial Law Article is less than $500,000, only the balance may be transferred in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Nonstate funds received by the Corporation shall be accounted for and reported as receipts and disbursements separate and distinct from State funds.
There is a Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund.
The Administrative Office of the Courts shall administer the Fund.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money deposited to the Fund from the surcharge assessed in civil cases under §§ 7–202 and 7–301 of the Courts Article;
money appropriated to the Fund under § 11–401 of this subtitle;
interest on attorney trust accounts paid to the Fund under § 10–303 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Corporation shall use the Fund to provide funding for civil legal services to indigents under this title.
The Treasurer shall:

paragraph.text: invest and reinvest the Fund in the same manner as other State funds; and
credit any investment earnings to the Fund and may not charge interest against the Fund if the average daily net cash balance for the month is less than zero.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund shall be made in accordance with an appropriation requested by the Judicial Branch of the State government under § 7–108 of the State Finance and Procurement Article and approved by the General Assembly in the State budget or by the budget amendment procedure under § 7–208.1 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: The Corporation shall accept and use any money or property received by gift, devise, bequest, or otherwise to further the purposes of this title.
The Corporation may not issue stock or declare or pay dividends.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to reasonable compensation paid for services rendered to or for the Corporation.
Net earnings of the Corporation may not inure to the benefit of any individual.

subsection.text: An individual may not share in the distribution of corporate assets on dissolution of the Corporation.

section.text: On the liquidation, dissolution, or winding up of the Corporation, after payment of the obligations and liabilities of the Corporation, all of the assets of the Corporation shall be transferred to one or more corporations or associations that:

paragraph.text: have a character or purpose similar to the Corporation’s;
are selected by the Board; and
qualify under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.
The accounts of the Corporation shall be audited annually.
The audits shall be conducted in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards by an independent certified public accountant.
An audit under this section shall be conducted where the accounts of the Corporation are normally kept.
If owned or in use by the Corporation and necessary to facilitate the audit, the Corporation shall make available to the auditor all:

subparagraph.text: books;
accounts;
financial records;
reports;
files; and
other papers or property.

paragraph.text: Full facilities for verifying transactions with the balances and securities held by depositories, fiscal agents, and custodians shall be available to the auditors.

subsection.text: The report of the annual audit shall:

paragraph.text: be submitted to the Governor, the Department of Budget and Management and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly; and
be available for public inspection during business hours at the principal office of the Corporation.
The audit authorized by this section is in addition to the annual audit required by § 11-407 of this subtitle.

For any fiscal year during which State funds are available to finance any portion of the operations of the Corporation, the Legislative Auditor may audit the financial transactions of the Corporation.
An audit under this section shall be conducted where the accounts of the Corporation are normally kept.
If owned or in use by the Corporation and necessary to facilitate the audit, the Corporation shall make available to the Legislative Auditor all:

subparagraph.text: books;
accounts;
financial records;
reports;
files; and
other papers or property.

paragraph.text: Full facilities for verifying transactions with the balances and securities held by depositories, fiscal agents, and custodians shall be available to the Legislative Auditor.
Unless the Legislative Auditor requires a longer period of retention, the items listed in paragraph (2) of this subsection shall remain in the possession and custody of the Corporation for 3 years.

subsection.text: The legislative audit shall be submitted to the General Assembly and the Governor, with any recommendations the Legislative Auditor considers advisable.

section.text: The Corporation shall make grants of financial assistance to grantees for the purpose of providing legal assistance to eligible clients.

subsection.text: The Corporation shall ensure that grants and contracts are made to:

paragraph.text: provide the most stable, economical, and effective delivery of legal assistance; and
provide access to legal assistance to eligible clients in all areas of the State.

subsection.text: The Corporation may not use a political test or political qualifications to select or monitor a grantee under this title.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a suspension or termination of financial assistance or a denial of an application for refunding because of a lack of available funds.
The Corporation shall prescribe procedures in accordance with this subsection to govern:

subparagraph.text: the suspension or termination of financial assistance; and
the denial of an application for refunding.

paragraph.text: The procedures shall ensure that financial assistance committed may not be suspended or terminated and an application for refunding may not be denied unless the grantee has been given:

subparagraph.text: reasonable notice; and
an opportunity for a timely, full, and fair hearing conducted by an independent hearing examiner.

subsection.text: In applying for and spending grant money from the Corporation, grantees shall consider the relative needs for service of clients, particularly the needs of eligible clients who have special difficulties of access to legal services or who have special legal problems, including elderly individuals and individuals with disabilities.
Funds provided to grantees under this title may not be used:

paragraph.text: to provide legal assistance for a fee-generating case;
to provide legal assistance for the defense of a criminal prosecution;
to provide legal assistance in a civil action to a person who has been convicted of a criminal charge if the civil action:

subparagraph.text: arises out of an alleged act or failure to act; and
is brought against an official of the court or a law enforcement official to challenge the validity of the criminal conviction;

paragraph.text: to influence the issuance, amendment, or revocation of an executive order or similar promulgation by a federal, State, or local unit, or to influence the passage or defeat of legislation by the United States Congress, or by a State or local legislative body, or a State proposal by referendum or petition;
to contribute to or be made available to a political party or association or the campaign of a candidate for public or party office; or
to provide representation in a class action suit.

subsection.text: The Corporation may require a grantee to submit any reports the Corporation considers necessary regarding activities carried out under this title.

paragraph.text: The Corporation may require grantees to keep records regarding funds provided by the Corporation.
The Corporation shall have access to the records at all reasonable times to ensure compliance with the grant or contract or the terms and conditions on which financial assistance was provided.

subsection.text: Each year, the Corporation shall require:

paragraph.text: a financial audit by an independent certified public accountant of each grantee whose grant income from the Corporation in the most recently completed fiscal year was $50,000 or more; or
a financial review by an independent certified public accountant of each grantee whose grant income from the Corporation in the most recently completed fiscal year was less than $50,000.

subsection.text: The report of each audit or review shall be:

paragraph.text: submitted to the Governor;
made available to the Legislative Auditor; and
kept for at least 5 years at the principal office of the Corporation.

section.text: The Corporation shall seek to ensure that a grantee providing legal assistance to eligible clients:

paragraph.text: maintains the highest quality of service and professional standards;
preserves attorney-client relationships; and
protects the integrity of the adversary process from any impairment.

section.text: Each application for legal assistance shall be in writing and accompanied by an affidavit stating that the information contained in the application is true and correct.

paragraph.text: The Corporation shall establish maximum income levels for client eligibility.
The income levels shall be based on the financial ability of a client to pay for competent private counsel and all other necessary expenses of representation.

subsection.text: The maximum income levels established under this section and eligibility guidelines established by each grantee to implement this section shall take into consideration:

paragraph.text: the size of the client’s family;
cost of living variations, including differences between urban and rural areas;
the assets and income of the client;
the fixed debts and medical expenses of the client; and
other factors relevant to the client’s ability to pay for the legal services the client requires.

subsection.text: The Corporation may not set the maximum income levels for eligibility under this section at a level greater than 50% of the median family income for the State as certified annually by the United States Department of Health and Human Services.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, information subject to the attorney-client privilege is confidential and may not be disclosed to any person unless the privilege is waived by the client or a court orders the disclosure.

subsection.text: A person may not obtain, attempt to obtain, or aid another person in obtaining or attempting to obtain legal assistance to which the person is not entitled by:

paragraph.text: willfully making a false statement or representation;
willfully failing to disclose a material change in financial condition;
impersonating another; or
any other fraudulent means.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

subparagraph.text: A person convicted under this section shall make full restitution of the value of the legal assistance unlawfully received.
The person shall be given notice and the opportunity for a hearing on the amount and terms of the payment.

section.text: The Corporation may not:

paragraph.text: participate in litigation, unless:

subparagraph.text: the Corporation or a grantee is a party; or
a grantee is representing an eligible client in litigation in which the interpretation of this title or a guideline established by the Corporation under this title is an issue;

paragraph.text: interfere with a lawyer’s professional responsibilities to clients under the Maryland Rules of Professional Conduct;
compete directly or indirectly with any grantee;
contribute or make available the Corporation’s funds or services to a political party or association or the campaign of a candidate for public or party office;
except as provided in §§ 501(h) and 4911 of the Internal Revenue Code:

subparagraph.text: carry on propaganda or otherwise attempt to influence legislation; and
participate or intervene in a political campaign on behalf of a candidate for public office, including publishing or distributing statements;

paragraph.text: notwithstanding any other provision of this title, conduct or carry on activities not authorized for an organization:

subparagraph.text: qualified under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code; or
to which contributions are deductible under § 170(c)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Legal Services Corporation Act”.
